Play details
The northern lasse. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1632. Date first performed: 29 Jul 1629 ?
THE NORTHERN LASSE, A COMOEDIE. As it hath beene often Acted with good Applause, at the Globe, and Black- Fryers. By his Maiesties Servants.
Front matter
Hic totus volo rideat Libellus. Mart.
The Persons in the Comedie.
Sir Phillip Lucklesse, Contracted to Mistresse Fitchow the Citie Widdow. Master Tridewell, Kinsman to Sir Phillip. Sir Paul Squelch Iustice; Mistresse Fitchows friend. Master Bulfinch Iustice; Mistresse Fitchows friend. Master Widgine a Cockney-Gentleman, Brother to Mistresse Fitchow. Anuile, a Braggart, Governour to Widgine. Master Non-sence a Cornish Gentleman, Suiter to Constance. Pate, a witty Seruingman to Sir Phillip. Beauis, a blunt Seruingman to Mistresse Traynwell. Howdye, Mistresse Fitchows man and Gentleman Vsher. Vexhem, a Constable. Cleark to Sir Paul. Masquers. Mistresse Fitchow, the Citie Widdow. Constance, the Northern Lasse. Mistresse Traynwell her Governesse. Con. Holdup, a cunning Whore. Chambermayd to Mistresse Fitchow.
TO THE RIGHT WORTHY AND NO LESSE IVDICIOUS then ingenious Gentleman Richard Holford Esquire.
SIR: Rich Friends may send you rich Presents, while poore ones haue nothing but good wishes to- present you. Though I bee one of the last ranke, and therefore cannot doe like the first, yet it is my ambition to bring more then bare wishes with me, to one of whom I haue receiued reall favours A Countrey Lasse I present you, that Minerua -like was a brayn-borne child; and Iouially begot, though now shee seekes her fortune. Shee came out of the cold North, thinly clad: But Wit had pitty on her; Action apparrell'd her, and Plaudits clap'd her cheekes warme. Shee is honest, and modest, though she speake broad: And though Art never strung her tongue; yet once it yeelded a delightfull
sound: which gain'd her many Lovers and Friends, by whose good liking she prosperously liued, vntill her late long Silence, and Discontinuance (to which shee was compell'd) gaue her iustly to feare their losse, and her owne decay. Wherefore shee, now, desirous to settle her selfe in some worthy seruice; And no way willing (like some of further breed) to returne from this Southern sunshine, back to her natiue Ayre; I thought it might become my care (having first brought and estrang'd her from her Countrey) to sue, with her, for Your noble Patronage; of Whom, shee heares, (if Flattery abuse her not) shee hath, heretofore, gotten some good opinion. Your loue to witty, and pleasant Recreations of this nature hath brought her on: And Northern Spirits will soone wex bold. If you be pleased to accept of her, shee will travaile no further; but, together with my selfe, remaine Euer at your seruice, Ric. Brome.
To my old Faithfull Seruant: and (by his continu'd Vertue) my louing Friend: the Author of this Work, M. Rich. Brome. [By Jonson, B.]
I Had you for a Seruant, once, Dick Brome; And you perform'd a Seruants faithfull parts: Now, you are got into a nearer roome, Of Fellowship, professing my old Arts. And you doe doe them well, with good applause, Which you haue iustly gained from the Stage, By obseruation of those Comick Lawes Which I, your Master, first did teach the Age. You learn'd it well; and for it, seru'd your time A Prentise-ship: which few doe now a dayes. Now each Court-Hobby-horse will wince in rime; Both learned, and vnlearned, all write Playes. It was not so of old: Men tooke vp trades That knew the Crafts they had bin bred in, right: An honest Bilbo -Smith would make good blades, And the Physician teach men spue, or shite; The Cobler kept him to his nall; but, now Hee'll be a Pilot, scarce can guide a Plough. Ben. Ionson.
To his approued Friend M. Richard Brome on his Northern Lasse. [By F. T.]
What ! wilt thou prostitute thy Mistresse, (Friend) And make so rich a Beauty common? What end Do'st thou propose? Shee was thine owne, but now All will enioy her free: 'tis strange that thou Canst brooke so many Riualls in thy Lasse, Whose Wit and Beauty does her Sex surpasse. I'ue learnt it; Thou hast tri'd her, found her chast, And fear'st not that Shee'll lewdly be embrac't: And now thou sendst her to be seene, and see If any be like faire, like good as Shee. F. T. Mag. Art. Oxon.
To his ingenious Brother M Rich. Brome, vpon this witty issue of his Brayne, the Northern Lasse. [By Brome, S.]
Although I call you by a Brothers name, I must confesse (nor doe I feare the shame) I am in loue with your faire Daughter, this, As faire condition'd as her Father is. Well met abroad, blithe, bonny, Northern Lasse: Thy naturall Beauties, others farre surpasse That are enrich'd with Pucusses of Art, Thy witty sweetnesse beares so faire a part. Not a Good woman, nor a Girle worth Gold, Nor twenty such (whose gaudy shewes take hold Of gazing eyes) shall in acceptance thriue With thee, whose quaintnesse is superlatiue. Dick may be proud shee's Daughter to no other; As I am proud that I haue such a Brother. St. Br.
Of M r. Richard Brome his ingenious Comedy, the Northern Lasse, To the Reader. [By Ford, J.]
Poets and Paynters curiously compar'd Giue life to Fancie; and atchieue Reward By Immortality of Name: So thriues Art's Glory, that All, what it breathes on, liues. Witnesse this Northern Piece. The Court affords No newer fashion, or for Wit, or Words. The Body of the Plot is drawne so faire, That the Soules language quickens, with fresh ayre, This well-limb'd Poem, by no Rate, or Thought Too dearely priz'd, being or sold, or bought. Iohn Ford The Authors very Friend.
To my Sonne Brome and his Lasse. [By Dekker, T.]
VVhich, then of Both shall I commend? Or Thee (that art my Sonne and Friend) Or Her, by Thee begot? A Girle Twice worth the Cleopatrian Pearle. No: 'tis not fit for Me to Grace Thee, who art Mine; and to thy Face. Yet I could say, the merriest Mayd Among the Nine, for Thee has layd A Ghyrlond by; and Iieres to see Pied Ideots teare the Daphnean Tree; Putting their Eyes out with these Boughes With which Shee bids me deck thy Browes. But what I bring shall crowne thy Daughter (My Grand child ) who (though full of laughter) Is Chast and Witty to the Time; Not Lumpish-Cold, as is her Clime. By Phoebus Lyre, Thy Northern Lasse Our Southern proudest Beauties passe: Be Iouiall with thy Braynes (her Mother) And helpe her ( Dick ) to such Another. Tho. Dekker.
To his knowne Friend Mr. R Brome on his Northern Lasse. [By F. T.]
My Loue may wrong thee, Friend; and, should I praise Thy Booke, I feare 'twould stayne the wreathing Bayes That crownes thy Head: No, they that know, can tell This Piece craues not a bribing Prayer to sell. Here's Beauty, Wit, and Language in a Glasse. Who would not haue a Copy of this Lasse ? F. T.

The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Anuile Bullfinch Constance Beauis Pate Mistress Fitchow Traynwell Howdye Con Holdup Maid Clerk Sir Phillip Lucklesse Masquer Non-sence
Prologue
Sir Paul Squelch Tridewell

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.p: Gallants, and Friends spectators, will ye see A strain of Wit that is not Poetry? I have Authority for what I say: For He himself says so, that Writ the Play, Though, in the Muses Garden he can walk; And choicest Flowers pluck from every stalk To deck the Stage; and purposeth, hereafter, To take your Judgments: now He implores your laughter; Says He would see you merry; thinks it long Since you were last delighted with a Song. Your Books, he says, can show you History; And serious Passages better than He; And that He should take pains in Act to show What you already by your Studies know Were a presumption. It is a Modesty Unused amongst Poets. This being only He That boasteth not his worth; and doth subscribe Himself an under-servant in their Tribe. Yet though he slight himself, We not despair, By him, to show you what is Good and Rare.

div2.stage:
Main text
Act. I. Sce. I. Enter Sir Phillip Luckles. Tridewell.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But I beseech you sir, Take me somewhat nearer your Council. May I assure myself, that this report goes true; that you are on this treaty of Marriage with that Widow?

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.p: Faith cousin, I take it as my fortune; and am fully bent on the adventure.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Troth in my mind, you were better venture yourself, and fortune to the Bermudas. It is true, she has a good estate: some nine thousand, I think: and were an apt match for one that knew how to govern it, and her; some hard bred Citizen, crafty Lawyer, or country Justice. But you, a tender Nursling of the Court, altogether unmixed with such nature or education, to cast yourself upon her, who for her years might be your Mother (they say: I never saw her) and has been the Town widow these three years, still conversant with Doctors, and Proctors of the civil Law; of which Tribe her husband was too. Never look to be the better for her Riches: She will consume yours and you too; though your back were Herculean; and lay you in your grave, or in Bedlam (my life on it) before she dream of dying, though it be all that you can hope, or pray for, after Marriage.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You speak sir out of some unfortunate examples, and your extraordinary care of me. But truth is, all dissuasion comes too late; and all urgings against it are now uncharitable: For we are already Man and Wife.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What married!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Lustily promised sir. Absolutely contracted.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Send you joy. I will out of Town.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I hope you will see our Marriage. I sent indeed to bid you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: No, good sir Phillip, rather than I would be in sound of a Bell that should ring at it, I would have my brains filliped out with the Clapper.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay good cousin: I intended you my principal Guest. We will have all very private: not above four or five friends more.

sp.speaker: Tri.
Luc.
sp.p: Indeed this is very abrupt.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Master. Tridewell! well met. Why so fast sir, I took you for a Foot-post.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: A Foot-post! Indeed your fine wit will post you into another world one of these days, if it take not the whipping post in the way. And why Foot-post, in your little witty apprehension?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Because you went so fast. But since you are angry, I would you were going twice as fast. If I interrupt you, hang me. Dee hear?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Nay, I know you are apt to decline any man's anger, good Captain Anvil: you have been beaten to it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, if he have, he may thank such as you are, that can endure no jest.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What are you there too? Master. Widgine, I take it?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My name is Walter Widgine sir, not to be denied, the only brother here of sir Phillip Luckless his betrothed. She is a Widgine born sir, and of the best family: Our Ancestors flew out of Holland in Lincolnshire to prevent persecution.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: From Crowland, I warrant you, a little before a Moulting time.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Like enough sir. My sister can tell you. Since, by marriage, she was made a Fitchow: Her husband was Fitchow the civil Lawyer; He was called the great Cannoneer of the civil Law: because he could discharge or make report of every Canon therein; Canon after Canon, or Canon upon Canon at his fingers ends, as readily as I can tell these pieces.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: A fair Demonstration!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: He had many rare parts in him, besides sir, as my sister can tell you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: This fellow cannot choose but have a rare sister: He quotes her so!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But all the good I can speak of him is, that he left my sister rich; or at least a reasonable estate, half a score thousand pounds or so: which she, with herself, bestows upon this honourable knight sir Phillip Luckless, to be a Lady of that name, and God give him joy. And for you: being his kinsman, I shall desire your nearer acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: In good time sir.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: The match was not altogether her own seeking sir, though she refused two Aldermen for him, on my own knowledge.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Might she have had them both sir?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Aye and half a score Aldermen's fellows to boot: yet refused all for him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Indeed six yoke of such cattle would plough up all his acres in a forenoon.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My sister can tell you more sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Still she is his Authority. I will see this woman. Sir Phillip, here are Guests will applaud your match. Bid them welcome. God buy.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
For my part I honour any Man, that marries my
sister. Sir Phillip, and my noble brother in expectation, I pray embrace my Governor, Captain Anvil, here; and give him and me our gloves: you shall find him worthy your acquaintance. He has wit, I can tell you; and breaks as many good jests as all the Wits, Fits, and Fancies about the Town, and has trained up many young gentlemen, both here, and in divers parts beyond the Seas. He was dry nurse (that is one of his own jests upon himself) to the English youth, a dozen years together beyond Sea: And now he is my Governor, and I find profit in it: you cannot think what an ass I was before I met with him: And I mean to travel with him, two or three years hence, myself. In the mean time, he shall spend a hundred a year out of Wat Widgines purse. Shalt I'faith Governor, what ailest thou? art thou not right?

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: I shall find a time to right myself, I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But will you travel at these years Master Widgine?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will you not call me brother? Two days hence when you have married my sister, you must. Must he not, Governor?

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Yes if it please him.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: He ails something.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well then, Brother two days hence, will you travel?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Aye some two years hence, mistake me not. I know I am but young yet: besides I mean to marry first as other young heirs do. And then towry lowry, faith, my noble Governor, and I! It will be brave going into France then: I may learn half their fashions before I go, and bate so much, being taught at when I come there. What is the matter Governor? thou wert not wont to be thus. Is thy money all gone? Here is five pieces to buy pomps against my sisters wedding.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Have I eyes and ears, and can think of trifling Money matters?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Pox on it I had forgot. That scurvy surly gentleman angered him ere while, and put him out of patience. How the hot foam of his rage boils out at his Mouth! If I durst
go so near the heat of him I would skim the pot.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: If I try not this Tridewell; put him to the dearest trial of his life.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Aye there it is, he will never come to himself till he beat, or be beaten.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Let me have these knocked out; these pulled off; these plucked out, and these sawed off.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I must venture on him. Nay Governor: pray thee consider.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: The time and place you mean. Think you he durst have done it, but in his kinsman's house; he and the multitude of his servants present.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Aye, and we know not how many armed men in the next room. Hark Governor.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What things are these! I shall marry into a fine stock! How untimely some considerations fall into my mind! My Cousins council, which hath ever been oraculously good; against which I violently bear myself, to mix my blood amongst a race of fools. Had but these thoughts been mine but one day past, they had prevented all that may prove dangerous in this, so great and doubtful undertaking.

div2.stage: Sce. III. Enter Pate, to Luckles, VVidgine, Anvile.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Sir, there is a gentlewoman would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who is it? Do you not know her?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I never saw her before sir. I asked her name. But I perceived some displeasure in her look (whether it were shame, grief, or anger I know not) that made her conceal it: Only telling me she was a woman very hurtless, and warrantable against your fear.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
I warrant it is my sister. She frowned, did she not, and looked fightingly? If she did, it is my sister, your wife that shall be. She will look so at you, I can tell you, or me, or my Governor, for all he is a Captain. She fears no colours In faith, to tell you true, she beat him once for a
jest he broke upon her Monkey. Is it not she, thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No sir it is not she. I know my Lady that shall be.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My Lady that shall be! how sweetly it chimes. Here is something for that word.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go bring her up. Good brother VVidgine, fly into the next room, with your Governor. I will wait on you presently.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: My Lady! And brother VVidgine! I must admire. Our house is raised by this two stories higher.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There is no recalling time; and vows of this high nature are no trifles.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir I suppose you are sir Phillip Luckless.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am the man Lady.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: And you are shortly to marry a City Widow, one Mistress Fitchow?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Most true.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: For whose dear sake you purchased a four hundred pounds knighthood, to go a wooing in: out of which she is to give nine thousand pounds for a Ladyship for term of life.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What mean you Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir not to scold, or brawl, (a vice too frequent in our Sex.) But, in few words (and civil ones) to make you sensible of a little of that infinite injury, you have done to one, whose unvaluable portion of virtue makes her fit, (besides the right she has already in you) to take a brides place, before your later choice, or any she, whose wealth might weigh down hers. You stand as if you knew not who I mean.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nor what neither. Sure my name is abused.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Pray sir bethink yourself. Has there not been a former contract made betwixt you and some other.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No. Nor any faithful promise neither.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: That I may well believe, when you forget it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I pray speak nearer to my understanding: whom may you suggest to be the woman so much forgotten?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: If you have soul, or sense, you must remember her: No? Read then her name subscribed to that.
If pity, love, or thought of me, Live in your breast I need not die. But if all these from thence be fled; Live you to know, that I am dead.

sp.speaker: Constance.
sp.p: Farewell good Constance. I am sorry I have no further for thee.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Do you know that name sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
Tri.
sp.p: Pray sir, are you in sober earnest?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In good faith am I.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You are unhappy then. For you shall lose, in this disdain of yours, more honour than your life time in repentance can recover. So fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Farewell old Whiskin. 'slid I will marry out of the way; it is time I think: I shall be taken up for whores meat else. Constance! she had a Bastard the other day too. What a mischievous Maw has this she Cannibal that gapes for me! 'slight a common Trader, with I know not how many! I marvel she was left out of Cupids Muster. Sure she bribed the Ballad-maker: One that I have paid at all times too; here is one, there is the other. And now she hears I am towards marriage pretends a claim to me. And what a Minister she had procured! A Devil in a most gentlewoman-like apparition. It had been well to have pumped her. Is she gone?

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Who sir, the Gentlewoman? I put her in her coach.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Her Coach! Coaches must needs be common, when their carriages are so. By this light, Oliver, a Bawd; a very Bawd. Where is my brother Widgine, and his Governor, Anvil? They are wholesomer company of the two, yet.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: A Bawd! Bless my Masters wits. But the best is, if he be mad, there is that at hand will tame him, or any man: A fine Cooler, called Marriage, to take his bachelors button a hole lower! Can it be possible? She might have been Mother of the Maids, as well, to my seeming; or a Matron, to have trained up the best Lady Daughters in the Country. Here comes her Man, again.

div2.stage: Sce. V. Enter Beavis, to Pate.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: Is sir Phillip Luckless in the house still sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Are you the Cock bawd to the hen was here, ere while sir.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: Are you mad, or are you drunk sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Come you to bargain for a Punk sir? Faith where is the meeting? Where is the Supper? at the Bridgefoot, or the Cat? or where is it?

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: Nay then sir, though your Master be allowed to measure his manners, by his pleasure, here, on his own yard, I will be bold to pull you out on it by the ears, and beat you into better fashion.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Hold, hold. Pray hold a little sir. I cry you mercy. I might be mistaken. I see thou art a good fellow. I have half a dozen for thee faith. 'sfoot what big words and terrible action he has! Is this the Bawds language? Pray pardon me sir: I have been overwatched of late, and knew neither place, person, nor what I said at the instant.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Aye sir, it is an infirmity I am much troubled withal; a kind of a between sleep and waking I know not what to call it. I would give twenty nobles to be cured on it. I pray take it not ill sir; I use any man so, when the fits on
me, till they thoroughly wake me.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: What as I did now? by the ears? Are you come to yourself enough yet? or shall I help you further sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No, it is very well now I thank you sir. Alas I put my Master to the pains, twice or thrice a week, I assure you, to my grief.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: A very strange disease! How might you get it?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Faith I fell into it first, with a conceit I took for overbuying a bargain of Drink. Your business with my Master sir? I pray.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: Only to speak with him from the Gentlewoman was here even now.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I shall acquaint him with it.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: I shall be your servant.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I pray pardon my error.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: And you my boldness.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: O not so sir. Well master Pimp I have a plot upon your employment, as bravely as you carry it. I know he is a Bawd by his outfacing. And I do humble and disguise my Manhood to work on him by policy: And if I put not a fine slur upon him for all his brave bravadoes, then Oliver Pate has no brains; nor is there any difference betwixt a Serving-man and a Pander.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: What a Trim-tram trick is this? the Master and the Man both brain-crazed; as the one used me, so did the other my Mistress. But I have brought this into a kind of civil sense again. Do we look like Bawds? There is some strange ground for this mistaking. I am sure she has ever been reputed a virtuous Gentlewoman; and has now the government, and bringing up of a Virgin, of a most hopeful goodness. And I think, I know myself; and dare beat any Man into a better construction of my quality.

sp.speaker: Pa.
Be.
sp.p: Between four, and five in the Palace: but how shall I know him? I never saw him.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: As I wished: But you may easily. He is of a comely stature; and will be in a red cloak and a white Feather. Besides I will wait on him.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Fare you well sir. Good Foist, I shall make a Whiskin of you now, and for nothing too. I have been a little bold with my Masters name in this answer; the knowledge of which he is unguilty of. I saw how he shifted her off: Therefore I will further be bold both with his name and person, which I will put upon a friend in store. My special friend, Captain Anvil, a notable lecherous Tup: He has been at me for a bit out of my Masters flock any time these three weeks. I will pleasure him with her for ready money. I know it is some cast stuff, that my Master has done withal. And let him take what follows.

div2.stage: Ex. Sce. VI. Enter Fitchow, Howdee, with Inke and Paper.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well sir. And what said Master Luckless?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Sir Phillip you mean forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: The very same sir. But I begin to call him now, as I must call him hereafter. Ladies do not call their husbands, as they are Knights: as sir Phillip, sir Timothy, or sir Gregory. Did you ever hear my Lady Squelch call her husband sir Paul? No. But master Squelch. Indeed all others must sir them by their Christen names; because they are Knights, and to be known from other men: only their own wives must master them, by their Surnames; because they are Ladies, and will not know them from other men. But to our business. What said he to you?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: His worship said forsooth

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Nay, What said you to him first? I love to hear things in order.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I said that as you bad me forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: As I bad you, Clotpoll? what was that? Shall I ever mold thee into a Gentleman Usher thinkst thou, that standest so? Come forwards sir, and repeat.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: My Mistress commends her best love unto your Worship; and desires to know how your Worship came home last night; and how your Worship have rested; and how your Worship does this morning? She hopes the best of your Worships health; and would be glad to see your Worship at your Worships best leisure.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: This was very well: word for word as I instructed. But did you worship him so much?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Yes truly, and he commended me for it; and said I showed my breeding.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Now sir. His answer? in his own words.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Quoth he. I thank thy Mistress, and I thank thee. Prithee commend my service to her, and tell her, my worship came home upon my worships Foot-cloth; my worship took very good rest, in my worships bed: My worship has very little to do this Morning, and will see her at my worships leisure.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Did he say so?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: It was either so, or so much I am sure. But he did not make me repeat, as you did, till I had conned it by heart.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well Howdee get you down. And do you hear Howdee? If sir Paul Squelch come, bring him up.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I will forsooth Mistress.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I bad you learn to call me Madam.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I shall forsooth Madam.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: You shall forsooth Madam. It is but a day to it; and I hope one may be a Lady one day before her time.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: A day too soon I doubt in this forward age.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
In the mean time, let me study my remembrances for after marriage. Imprimis, To have the whole sway of the house; and all domestical affairs; as of accounts of household charges, placing and displacing of all servants in general; To have free liberty, to go on all my visits; and though my knights occasions be never so urgent, and mine of no moment, yet
to take from him the command of his Coach; To be in special fee with his best trusted servant; nor to let one live with him, that will not bewray all his counsels to me. To study and practise the Art of jealousy; To feign anger, melancholy, or sickness, to the life. These are Arts that women must be well practised in, ere they can attain to wisdom, and ought to be the only study of a widow, from the death of her first husband, to the second: From the second to the third, matters of deeper moment; From the third to the fourth deeper yet; And so proportionably to the seventh, if she be so long blessed with life: But of these I may find time hereafter to consider in order as they fall. Besides, in all, to be singular in our will; to reign, govern, ordain laws and break them, make quarrels and maintain them; profess truths, devise falsehoods; protest obedience, but study nothing more than to make our husbands so; Control, controvert, contradict, and be contrary to all conformity: To which end we must be sure to be armed always with prick and praise of the deceased; and carry the Inventory of our goods, and the gross sum of our Dowry perpetually in our mouths. Then does a husband tickle the spleen of a woman, when she can anger him to please him; chide him to kiss him; Mad him to humble him; make him stiff necked to supple him; and hard-hearted to break him; to set him up, and take him down, and up again, and down again, when, and as often as we list.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Aye marry, now thou sayst well.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: If it please your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well said again.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: One Master. Tridewell, a Gentleman, desires to speak with your Ladyship, from Sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Tridewell! O it is Sir Phillips Kinsman. I have heard him speak much good of him; and entreated me to give him good respect; which were enough to mar his entertainment, had I not another purpose of mine own, that may prove as ill. Bring him up Howdee.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I will Madame

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Aye that was very well. This Howdee do I mean with a cast Gown to put in apparel, and make my Gentleman Usher; Not only for the aptness of his name, to go on my visits; but for his proportionable talent of wit and manners.

div2.stage: Sce. VII. Enter Tridewell to Fitchow,

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: If I can yet redeem him, he is happy. By your leave Lady: May my boldness prove pardonable?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sir the name of him, you come from, is warrant sufficient to make your welcome here: All that is here being his.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Is this she trow?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I understand you come from Sir Phillip Luckless.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: It is true, I brought his name thus far to enter me to your presence. But here I shake it off, as I would do his remembrance: but that I know him too well.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Too well Sir? How mean you?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Too well indeed Lady; but in the ill part. I know him to be no equal Match for you. Yet I hear you receive him as a Suitor.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Right Sir. And him only.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: It is not gone so far I hope.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Beshrew me but it is; and farther too Sir. He has all wooed and won me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Beshrew your fortune then. And if my counsel; The friendliest counsel ever you hearkened to, Stop not your venturous foot from one step further, (For now you are upon the brink of danger) You fall into a Sea of endless sorrows.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: This is pretty!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Look back into yourself; read over your Story, Find the content the quiet mind you lived in, The wealth, the peace, the pleasure you enjoyed; The free command of all you had beneath you, And none to be commanded by above you. Now glance your eye on this side, on the yoke, You bring your neck to, laden down with cares, Where you shall faintly draw a tedious life, And every step encounter with new strife. Then, when you groan beneath your burdenous charge, And wearily chance to revert a look Upon the price you gave for this sad thraldom, You will feel your heart stabbed through with many a woe, Of which one dies not while a thousand grow. All will be then too late: Now is the time, Now rings the warning bell unto your breast: Where if you can but entertain a thought, That tells you how you are beset with danger, You are secure; Exclude it, you are lost To endless sorrows, bought with dearest cost.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Pray Sir deal freely with me. What respect Moves you to make this strong dissuasion? Is it your care of me? or love of him?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p:
A subtle question! This woman is not brainless. Love of him Lady? If this can be love, To seek to cross him, in so great a hope, As your enjoying; being all the means, Or possibility he has to live on; If it be love to him, to let you know How lewd and dissolute of life he is, By which his fortunes being sunk, he is grown The scorn of his acquaintance, his friends trouble, Being the common borrower of the Town. A Gallant lights not a Tobacco Pipe, But with his borrowing letters (she is not moved) And if you put him off a fortnight longer, He will be laid up for moneys he took up To buy his Knighthood; besides his deep engagements
To Goldsmith, Silkman, Taylor, Milliner, Sempster, Shoemaker, Spurrier, Vintner, Tapster, (All stirs her not, she stands as if prepared To hear as much of truth and bear with it.) Men of all Trades, and Occupations, From his Mercer downward to his Waterman, Have ventured the last sixpence on his Credit; And all but wait to pay themselves from you. And I may well imagine how it would grieve A woman of your wealth, to disburse all, To save a Knight out of his Ward in the Counter; And lack with all his company at home; While he frequents youthful society To make more charge for Nurseries abroad: For I have heard him say you are old; and that It is your wealth he marries, and not you. If this be love to him, that I discover (The means to save you to be his undoing,) Let no man take a friends help in his wooing.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: And how this should proceed from care of me Falls not into my understanding Sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Consider Lady

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sir I have considered Before, and in your speech, and since; and cannot By all that can be said remove a thought. I loved him not for words: Nor will I use Words against yours: it were poor expression Of love to boast it. It is enough I know it. Boasters of love, how can we Lovers call, When most of such love one no more than all.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sure, I was much mistaken in this woman.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Nor would I have you to expect a railing, To say you basely wrong the Gentleman: A way so common, common women use it. But this Sir I will say, I were too blame If I should think your love to him were less Than the great care of me, you seem to urge, As you pretend it is.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: She will discover me.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: You are his Kinsman nearly; and reputed, By his own mouth, his best of chosen friends; Myself an utter stranger, one from whom You never had, or can expect least good. And why you should, for a respect so contrary, Call my poor wit in question to believe you, Is most unconscionable.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Me think I stand Like a false witness against another's life, Ready to take his punishment.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Nor will I fondly think you meant to seek, Crossing his Match, to make it for yourself: Both for my known unworthiness; and your Depraving him being no possible way To make me think the better of your worth.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Can this be she? how strangely am I taken!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: But I forgive, and charitably think All this brought no ill purpose; pretty Pageantry Which may hereafter, among our marriage mirth, Fill up a Scene: for now I will take no notice. Indeed I will not: you may, if you please, And tell your Cuz how heinously I take it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: If thou hast mercy, Love, keep it from my heart. Will it please you hear me?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
Sir I have, enough. And crave but leave to speak this little to you, Which shall by heaven be uncontrolled as Fate. If I shall find him bad, I will blame my fortune: Never repent, or thank you for your counsel. If I shall find him good; and all this false, Which you so violently have urged against him; I will love him ne'er the more, nor you the worse: For I am not so poor, nor weakly spirited, That should all friends to whom my faith is bound, Say on their knowledge, that all this were true, And that one hours protraction of our Marriage Should make it appear, that I would give allowance
To all their bugbear reasons, to defer That hour the uniting of our hands: because Our hearts are linked by the Divinest laws.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What have I done? The curse of overweening brains, Shame, and disgrace are guerdon of my pains. O, I shall fall beneath the scorn of fools: A punishment as just, as great for such, That do in things, concern them not, too much.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: What ails the Gent?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: On what a settled rock of Constancy She planteth her affection? not to move, Though all the breath of slanderous reproach, Driving tempestuous clouds and storms of horror, Should beat, at once, against it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sir How dee?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Not you Sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I would I had not seen, at least not heard her In all so contrary to all opinion.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: You are not well Sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: They said she was old, unhandsome, and uncivil, Froward, and full of womanish distemper. She is none of these: but opposite in all.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
Fit.
sp.p: You are not going Sir?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I beg your pardon; dare not look upon you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Gone in a dream! Well, I perceive this juggling. This strain was only to explore the strength Of my affection to my luckless Knight. For which, if both their Cunnings I not fit, Let me be called the barren wife of wit.

div2.stage: The end of the first Act.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: The strangeness of this Gentleman's action will not out of my mind yet. Sir Phillip could not but have a hand in it. Does he repent his bargain already; and desire to be quit with loss of his earnest? It is but his faith and troth.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister, where are you? My Governor and I are come to wait upon you in sir Phillip Luckless coach. It waits at door for you; and what to do think you?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I cannot tell. Perhaps to invite me forth into the air of Hideparke or Maribone; or else

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Or else me no or else's, sister, you cannot guess it. And I was a fool to ask you the question, now I think on it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: That was well remembered brother.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister, you are to be a Lady, within this half hour. Your knight is ready, so is the Parson too. My Governor here knows.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Yes Lady; and that he entreats you, to bear with the suddenness of the occasion, which he protests, deeply urges him to be married presently; desiring you not to trouble yourself in examination of his reasons: for upon his honesty and honour, the end of it is for good to you both. Come sweet Madam (now I am bold to give you your dew title) your knight is ready pressed on his adventures (dee hear) and it is only you, that he seeks to encounter.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: There is a jest now: but she understands it not. He makes her an Infidel, a wild beast or a Monster, by that word Encounter; what do Knights adventurers encounter else? look all the Mirror over. He will encounter her. O the wit of a Governor!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: It is as I say Madam, (dee hear) the good fit has come on him.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ever at the tail of his dee hear, I am sure to smell a jest: the fits come on him!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
This sudden importunity confirms my former doubt: He thinks his Scarecrow will make me keep off
now; but he is cozened. Well sir. He shall find me obedient to his hand. I am in all prepared to meet his purposes; Though, Brother I had thought to had conference this Morning with sir Paul Squelch touching a match for you.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: For me sister! have you found out a wife for me? have you? pray speak, have you?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: And a good match too brother; Sir Pauls Niece: on whom, he, being childless, means to bestow a large Dowry.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By my faith, and he may do it. He is rich Governor; one of the best Ten in the hundred men about this Town.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: He is a right good man. Within there.
Bid Flaps your fellow bring my Fan and Masque.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Is he bounteous and liberal ha? Does he make large Suppers and lend money. Dee hear? Is he good at that?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, there you mistake Governor. A good man in the City is not called after his good deeds, but the known weight of his purse. One, whose name any Usurer can read without spectacles; One that can take up more with two fingers and a thumb upon the Exchange, then the great man at Court, can lift with both his hands; One that is good only in riches, and wears nothing rich about him but the Gout, or a thumb Ring with his Grandsires sheep mark, or Grannams butter print on it, to seal bags, acquittances and Counterpanes.

div2.stage: Enter Mayd, Howdee, with Maske and Fan.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: A Butter print?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Aye it were a cunning Herald could find better Arms for some of them: though I have heard sir Paul Squelch protest he was a gentleman, and might quarter a coat by his Wives side. Yet I know he was but a Grazier when he left the Country; And my Lord his father whistled to a team of horses (they were his own indeed.) But now he is right worshipful, and I would I had his Niece unsight and unseen I'faith for her monies sake. You never heard me ask if she were fair or handsome, dee mark that sister? My fathers rule right! And if I be not a true Widgine, (God forgive me) I think he was none.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: But she is very fair brother, and very handsome; and the prettiest innocent country thing withal. Do I want nothing here?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I now you bring me to bed sister.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Your Masque sits well forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: But where is my Wimple forsooth?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Upon the Cupboards head, pray Humfrey fetch it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: He lives not that loves a Country thing like me. Alas none loves a Country thing like me. And though I am a Cockney, and was never further than Hammersmith; I have read the Country man's common wealth; and can discourse of Soccage and Tenure, Free-hold, Copy-hold, Lease, Demeans, Fee-simple and Fee-tail, Ploughing, Hedging, Dyking, Grubbing, occupying any Country thing whatsoever; and take as much pleasure in it, as the best Clown born of them all.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: And she is very young, not above fifteen, brother. How this fellow stays! Go you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And that is a safe age for a Maid in the Country: dee hear?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pardon me Governor. I do hear and not hear thee at this time.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: And sings, and speaks so pretty northernly they say.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Is she Northern (dee hear) will she not shrink in the wetting?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Governor, I know thou spokest a jest now, by thy dee hear: but prithee forgive me; I cannot applaud nor mark thee at this time.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: What makes you stay so? I fear you have been among my sweet meats.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: She said it was upon the Cupboard; and it was under the Cupboard.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Is this my Wimple? Do you bring Carpenters tools to dress me withal.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Here is your Wimple forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
I shall teach you to know a difference between
gentlewomen's gear and Carpenters tools. I shall.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, she is so vexed now! Dear sister to the Country Lass again. You said, she spoke and sung Northernly. I have a great many Southern songs already. But Northern airs nips it dead. York York for my money.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Yes brother she is Northern, and speaks so: for she has ever lived in the Country, till this last week, her Uncle sent for her up to make her his child, out of the Bishopric of Durham.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Bishop, nor Bishopric shall hold her from me.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: And brother

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Sister no more, though I have never seen her. No Bishopric in the land from me shall win her. If you will go, and clap hands with your Knight, come; I would see you matched first: because that will add some honour to the Widgines, when myself shall be brother to a Lady. I shall write first of that name. And then am I no sooner married, Governor, but we will set our travels a foot: to know Countries, and Nations, Sects and Factions, Men and Manners; Language and Behaviour.
And so in height of complement grow complete More goes to making of a Man, than meat.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Pray tell me; and tell me truly. What is the most has past between you? If it be the main loss of your Maidenhead, it shall near go further: therefore let me know it.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.p: As I live Mistress Trainewell, all that ever he had of me was but a kiss. But I mun tell ye, I wished it a thousand, thousand till him.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: How often have you seen him?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Faith but that bare each other, and your self were by too. Trow ye that I would not tell ye and it were maer. By my conscience Mistress. Trainewell I lee not.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
That once that I saw him with you, your Uncle
was there, too, in the Orchard, but last week.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Vary true, Mine Uncle was then by too. And he brought sir Phillip to see his Orchard. And what did he then do, trow you, but took me thus by the hand, and thus he kissed me; he said I were a deft Lass: but there he feigned. But for my life I could not but think, he war the likest man that I had seen with mine eyen; and could not devise the thing I had, might be unbeggen by him. Then by and by as we walked, he asked mine Uncle, gin he would give him me to make a Lady till him. And by my troth Mistress Trainwell, I lee not, I blushed and looked upon him as I would feign a had it so: Mine Uncle said yes, and sir Phillip shook my hand, and good faith my heart joyed at it. God gin the Priest had been by. But I thought all sure enough; and would not have sold my part for the Spanish Ladies Jointure. But straight anon mine Uncle and he fell on other talk, of Lords and Ladies, and many fond like things, I minded not: For I is well sure, this kept me waking ere sine. And God pardon me what I misthought every hour in the night.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: How have you made me wrong this Gentleman, to challenge him as if he had been your due upon this idle complement? when I undertook the Message, I presumed (for so your words did intimate to me) you had been sure, as fast as faith could bind you, man and wife. Where was my discretion? Now I perceive this was but common Courtship; and no assurance of a Marriage promise.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I wot not what he meant. But I is well sure, I will never be sure to any Man but he. And if he love me not as well, God pardon him. For I meant him none ill.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I know not how to counsel or comfort you, until I hear him speak. My man tells me, he appointed him to meet, and bring him to you about this hour. Poor heart I pity thee. Before thou come to half my years thou wilt forget to love half so truly.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: O, are you come? where is the Knight?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: He stays below, and willed me to come up first, to make his passage clear and secure.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: That was discretion.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Rather fear I think: for he asked me if the house were not much haunted with Roarers of Swaggerers, poniards and pistols: whether there were not an Assurer for it as upon the Exchange, as if his life were upon hazard? whether a Man might come on without loss of credit, and off without need of a Surgeon? Much odd talk he delivers; that in my conceit bewrays, at once, both a lascivious and cowardly disposition; and upon my understanding, cannot be so generous, or nobly spirited, as he is received. Do what you will.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I suspect something.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Will he not come Mistress. Trainewell?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes sweetheart. But go you to your Chamber and let me have a word before you see him. Go call him in. Do so sweetheart. I will not be long.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I will do aught you bid me. God gin I saw him since.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: A place of fair promising! How have I lived that never discovered this place before? This place royal! But sought my recreation in by-lanes, and sluttish corners, unsavoury Allies and Ditch sides? when here the whole house is perfumed: An Earl might think it his own lodging; Ladies might come to see the pictures, and not blush, to go in or out unmasked.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, will you speak to my Mistress? The man is transported sure!

sp.speaker: An.
Tra.
sp.p: Bless me! this is another man. More abuse yet?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Now gentlewoman to you. What fees belong to your Key? Come, where is the bed? where is the party?
Here is the man: here is the money. Chunk chunk you old Gamester, dost hear? Here is half a piece to buy thee complexion, sack or Aqua-vitae. What thou likest.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: What are you sir I pray?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Faith one that is a little ill given at this time. Where is the Piece? here are the pieces I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: What piece sir? If you can imagine what you are, where you are, what you would have, or where you would be, I pray tell me sir. I will do the best I can to satisfy you. On my discretion will I sir.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Give me but a little space to wonder at thy strange demands and I will tell thee, good discretion. If I should purchase a broken Coxcomb, or bruised ribs now, for mistaking another man's habit, the smart were only mine. The villain swore to me, his Master was sent for; and that his Master swore this was a Bawd to his choice Whore, newly entertained; and that she knew not him, and might well mistake me for him. On which presumption I have waded thus far: and if I stick in the Mud, or be driven back by a tempest, I am armed. It is not the first time I have been Weather beaten, or Dry beaten, dee hear?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: You do not know me? or, at least, not remember me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: If I err therein sir, I hope your pardon. For as you shall reveal yourself, I shall either repent me of my oblivion, or accuse you of unadvisedness.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: She speaks like the wife of an Orator, that could dictate her husbands speeches! Were not you this Morning at sir Phillip Luckless lodging? spoke not you with him? sent you not for him afterwards to repair hither to the party? And know you not the man?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
O infinite abuse! Sir I cry you mercy. I hope you will pardon my weak sightedness. The worlds bad, and we love to deal securely. Could not your worship make yourself known sooner? Please you to entertain yourself here a while, I will instantly provide for your better welcome. O horrible indignity! But if Porters and cudgels
may be had for money, and I fit you not, let me lose my discretion. I am furnished with blankets already.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I will instantly provide for your better welcome! Will you so? It will pass: and by this light I think for my Masters jest: I will recover my charges, and gain over and above for three returns more with the bare repetition of it out of one man's purse, the Widgine. My jests are his nutriment; and my wit is his own, he pays so duly for it. If the Wench be but pleasing, now, to my expectation, my felicity is crowned.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: O child, we are undone.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Marry, God shield Mistress. Trainewell. Is he gone? Must I not see him?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: A lass it is not he: but some Villain sent by him to vex and spite you. One that persuades himself, we are of those common creatures, that sell their honesties.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Heaven bliss us, and give us leave to dee first. Can he be so unkind, to scorn me so. Woe is me.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: He is so dishonourable. But I will fit his Undertaker, what ever he be. Look you, is that he think you?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: O Well a near Mistress Trainewell! Sir Phillip is the likest man that ever you saw days of your life. This Losel does not. Nor would he send him. So trim a Man cannot have sike bad purpose.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: Mistress, there is a Gentleman, one Master Tridewell, that says he is sir Phillips Kinsman, will by all means speak with him.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sweet heart, can you dissemble your sorrow with a Song, to pass a little time? I will down and sift out the subtlety of this deceit.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: There is no government under the Sun, like the politic government of a Bawdy-house.

You say my Love is but a Man. But I can find more odds.
Betwixt him and others than I can, find between him and Gods. He has in his eye such Majesty. His shape is so divine. That were I Owner of the world. He only should be mine.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sweet prologue to the ensuing Interlude!
Dost hear me honest fellow? was this the Parties voice?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Only hers upon my sincerity sir.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Excellent! She has raised my desire above her notes. Why am I thus ravished, and yet delayed?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, for that my Mistress craves your Pardon. It is not her neglect, that works upon your patience; But the necessity to rid a troublesome Lord or two out of the house, before the Party can appear to you. But please you to obscure yourself in this dark Closet, while I convey them hence, and then, instantly, the top Gallant of pleasure shall crown your Main-mast, she says.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O how her wit and care revives me! From hence forth she is my Bawd for ever. My discretion! But are they wholesome Lords Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: It is no matter for anything they did here sir, I warrant you. In quickly pray sir.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Must I be locked in?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: You cannot be safe else sir.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The politic government of this little common wealth!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p:
Indeed Lady, I am so far from being in any plot herein, that I protest it was merely by his outside, and that in the doubtful light of the Evening, that I could guess it was he. And had he been denied, I had gone well satisfied, it had been some other man. Which if it prove, and so his name be abused Or if it be he indeed, though hitherto
my most respected Cousin, that offers such an outrage, as you deliver it to be: I am so much a friend to honesty, that let me but see the man or beast, I will do the fair office of a Gentleman to right you. Indeed Lady I will.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You profess nobly sir. First will it please you, see this Gentlewoman; so much the servant of your Kinsman? What she is I have told you. Only I present her to your judgment, whether her outward seeming may deserve such scorn?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Alas fair Lady, would they injure you?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Yea faith, and scorn me too sir. Ill betide them. But and you do me help, and master sir Phillip love me, God reward you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And has your youth and beauty placed your love on him?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Good faith sir, I may not say how well I love him: But were I one of near saint mickle, heest even have all. And yet he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Indeed it is pitiful. Weep not sweet Lady. He shall love ye.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Now Gods benison light on ye for it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Show me the mischief, that hath abused us all. Can you conceal him longer?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: In thus much, to conjure you by your Manhood; to do nothing that Law may question, to your, or our disadvantage: we shall not need, For our own right, to do ourselves misdeed. Therefore take this in hand. a Ropes end.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You do instruct me well. Pray let me see him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O for a large Window, one of the last edition, to leap out with half my life or limbs.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Lo ye lo ye, the worst like man to Sir Phillip, ye saw in all your days.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Mischievous Devil! What magical madness conjured you into this shape? Indeed I will conjure you out on it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O hold: for heavens sake hold. I will confess.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Nay, indeed I will beat you a little first, you will confess the better. It will come the easier from you. It is a good preparative.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O! O, I will confess anything.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: No sir, not anything. But the truth, the truth sir.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth so help me

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You would be swearing now would you? there is for that.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: No indeed, indeed, and indeed la I will not.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Good sir no more. What may this poor thing be, that braved it so but now?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I will tell you Lady. The most notorious, base, beaten Rascal about the Town. It were lost breath to say more by him. He is as you see. Only is name is Anvil: and they that know him not, call him Captain.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Anvil? Pray sir let me try my blade on him too.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I pray thee do, to save me a labour: for he is not half beaten yet.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O, O. Ladies speak for me. have you no mercy?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Hold. No more.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Well sir, thank the Ladies. Now sir, put this Ladies favour here in your pocket; and keep it there till I call for it. And mark what I say, if ever I find thee without this Instrument or the like, when I shall call for it, to beat thee (mark me) indeed I will beat thee dead. And now to your examination. How got your rotten Mutton ship into this Lions case? was it by the Owners knowledge? was the Master of these Clothes privy to your undertaking? Answer sirrah, bona fide, Aye or no.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: No upon my life; only his Man abused me for my Money.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What presumption made you think so vilely of these Gentlewomen?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir Phillips own words to his Man, upon a letter this Lady delivered to him this Morning.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p:
The Error is found. Her name you say is Constance,
which likewise is the name of a prostituted Strumpet, with whom, it is thought, the wantonness of his youth hath held former familiarity; and now it seems makes doubt, imagining that letter to be hers, that she pretends a claim to him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Right sir: which he took so contemptuously, that instantly he resolved to marry the Widow, Mistress Fitchow; and was this Morning married privately in a Chamber, within an hour after you saw him.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: And I undone then.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And I if it be so.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: It is undoubtedly true. I saw them married, and dined with them, at his lodging, where they will sup too: But after Supper they go to her house in the Town to bed.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: This foul mistaking we shall all repent; if we prevent not what may issue from it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Alas sir all will be too late.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Will you but trust my service for your honour?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: We will wait on you sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Then Sir for this time you shall be reprieved, From further penance: Rise and be our Guide. But keep your fear still: for if all our art Miscarry, thou art sure to share the smart.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Brother Humfrey, take my hand and word for thy instructions. I will acquaint thee with an old Ladies Usher, in the Strand, that shall give thee thy Gait, thy Postures, thy Language, thy Habit, and thy whole charge in so plain a Method, that thou shalt instantly start up as pretty a Gentleman Usher, none dispraised as any between Temple bar and Charing-cross; marry further I cannot promise you. But prithee tell me. Is our Lady of so hot a temper and stately carriage as she is reputed?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p:
O I brother. She must command all, or all shall smoke for it. She did so in my old Masters days I am sure.
And he glad of peace at that rate too.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: But how is she to her servants? Bountiful and free?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Yes both of her voice, and hands.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: She will not strike will she?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: And she could bite as well, the rankest Jade that ever was curried could not come near her.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Heaven be good to us! she ne'er struck thee, did she?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: It is no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Nay brother, you know we have vowed to be all one: the Marriage hath united us. Prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: She broke me a tooth once with a deaths Head ring on her finger? it had like to have cost me my life! it has been a true Memento to me ever since; bobs on the lips, tweaks by the nose, cuffs on the ear, and trenchers at my head in abundance.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Will she throw too?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Anything she can lift. and makes us pay for all she breaks, though she break our heads or faces withal. Fan handles, Looking-glasses or anything.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: We shall have a foul house on it I fear: But since it is too late, fight Dog, fight Bear. I will turn my Master loose to her. Here they come. By this light methinks they look as if they were fallen out already.

div2.stage: Sce. VI. Enter Lucklesse, Fitchow, Wayting-woman, Widgine, and Bulfinch. At the other dore Squelch, Nonsense, and Beauis.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Though I were absent at the Ceremony, I now bring my wishes of much joy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And not too late I hope sir Paul. We may yet carry them to bed with us.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: You had been chiefly sir invited, had we not stolen a day from Time, to have done a Fathers part at Church, to which in your absence, I entreated our worthy friend Master: Apprehension Bullfinch here.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Master Bullfinch, I rejoice to meet you here directly. Look you sir. Do you know this young Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Yes sure, methinks I should know him. But I am sure I never saw him before. ha

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Have you forgot sir Hercules?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend him to be Master Salomon Nonsense, Son and Heir to my right worthy friend, sir Hercules Nonsense of Cornwall. If you be not he sir. I am sure it is you. I may be deceived, but I am certain it is he.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He is doubtful, but yet he is sure he knows him. What a Bullfinch is this! sure it is his language they call bull speaking.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: You say very well sir. And never credit me as you knew my Father, I would be very ready, as you know how duty binds: for because it is a usual thing in these days, desiring the love and friendship, I protest and vow sir I should

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Most perfect Nonsense! this is a finer youth then the other. My wives acquaintance are most answerable to her Kindred.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: It is so directly Master Bullfinch, and I have brought him to Towne I understand my Niece is in your house, my Lady Bride. Is she employed in your Chamber?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: She is not here sir. Is she Howdee?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Certes no Madam.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: How! not here? Sirrah what did you tell me?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: What shall I say or do? I shall be hanged directly.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: How was she accompanied?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: By my Mistress sir, and two Gentlemen of her acquaintance, whose names I know not.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Knavery, Villainy and Thievery! I smell it rank. She has stolen, she has gone directly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It is indirectly sir if she be stolen. There your word fails you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: If she be in the land I will recover her. I hope I shall find as much right in Law, as a Broker or a Joiner.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Good sir Paul, I have not seen you thus distempered. What afflicts you?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: O Mistress Fitchow, my Niece, my Niece.

sp.speaker: Widg.
sp.p: He is mad I think. Sir you forget my sister is a Lady.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: She is lost, she is stolen, and all my joy is gone. My Niece, my Constance.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Constance!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Who your young Niece that came lately out of the Country?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: My Country thing sister, that you promised me?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Promised you? I am abused. I do suspect you accessories. Sir I have purposed and promised her to this Gentleman. And here I charge you to restore her me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Are you the Man sir that must have her?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Never credit me sir, if I have her, or have her not to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sir Phillip, you are courteous and noble: as you will continue so in opinion of honest men, let me have right.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir Paul, upon my faith I am ignorant of any such wrong. And, for her part, should she fare amiss, I should suffer in her injury equally with yourself: for I profess to you, I did love the Lass so well; and at the first sight, that had I not been otherwise allotted, and indeed contracted to her, from whom now there is no starting, she should have been my Bride, if all my love and fortune might have won her.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Had you spared this Protestation, Sir, you might have dissembled your love to me the better.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Dissemble?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: It is said sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By this hand my Lady is jealous already.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Bless us! what looks are these!

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sir I must take my leave, this is no time to trouble you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay good sir stay, and share in our ill Banquet. Hark, some friend I hope. Look sirrah. Cornets flourish.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Some of your old companions have brought you a fit of Mirth. But if they enter to make a Tavern of my house, I will add a voice to their consort shall drown all their fiddling. What are they?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Some that come in gentile fashion to present a Mask.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Lock up the doors, and keep them out.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Break them open and let them in

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Shall I not be Master of my own house?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Am not I the Master of it and you

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay sister.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Passion of my heart.

sp.speaker: Squ. Bull.
sp.p: Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: You must allow of reasonable things.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Be contented, sir Phillip is a noble Gentleman, and a Courtier, and as I apprehend.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I dare warrant you sister these are of his friends, that come with their Loves to congratulate his fortune. Speak Master Nonsense. A speech of yours would do it.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Never credit me, but I forsooth am of that opinion, that it is as it were. I protest and vow I should be as sorry as any Man.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If this were to be put into latin now. Which were the principal Verb.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Master. Nonsense, you have prevailed. You see I am content. But what I purpose, Fate shall not prevent.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Did I not tell you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: More lights, and let them enter. Gentlemen take your places. Sir Paul tonight forget your sorrow. So will I mine, though I renew it tomorrow. Come sit sit. Mistress please you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: You wrong your honour sir, your most humble Handmaid.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Brother I told you always she had hasty humours, and as unreasonable as heart can wish: but soon over. Now she is as mild as any Dove again.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then we are friends; and she is my Dove again.

div2.stage:
Musicke.
The Masquers Enter. All in willow Garlands. Foure Men. Foure Women. The two first payres are Tridewell and Constance. Anvile and Trainewell. Before the Daunce, Constance sings this Song.
Song.

sp.p:
Nor Love, nor Fate dare I accuse, For that my Love did me refuse; But O mine own unworthiness, That durst presume so mickle bliss. It was too much for me to love A Man, so like the Gods above; An Angels shape, a Saint-like voice,
Are too Divine for Human choice. O had I wishly given my heart, For to have loved him but in part; Sought only to enjoy his face; Or any one peculiar Grace Of Foot, of Hand, of Lip, or Eye, I might have lived where now I die. But I presuming all to choose Am now condemned all to lose.

div2.stage: At the end of the Daunce, Tridewell and Constance whisper with Anvile, each of them giuing him a folded paper.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It is well performed. Now we would gladly know. To whom we owe our thanks.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: That I will deliver to you. Mean while the rest desire they may withdraw a while.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Light and all fair respect be given unto them.

div2.stage: Exeunt all the Masquers but Anvile.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: The Woman's voice had much in it like my Niece.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your Niece sir Paul, odds me I must go see her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay brother give them all their free pleasures. By your leave you shall stay.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Shall I shall I? I will then.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Now to your patience I disclose myself.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Whoop! My Governor! Look you sister. Look you sir Phillip. Did nor I always tell you he was the rarest wit in the world? This was his own invention I will be hanged else. Sweet Governor the conceit of
the Willow, and why thou wearest it?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Myself, only to make the number in the Dance suitable. And so did all the rest to fulfil the fashion, only two excepted, that were the Leaders and subject of the Dance. The one, your Cousin Tridewell, who holds himself a lost Lover, in that you Madam to whom his affection is wholly devoted, have made yourself incapable of him, in being the lawful right of another. This paper shows him more at large.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is it possible! Did he for that so earnestly dissuade me from her this Morning?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I never saw him before this day, nor he me. These are tricks and studied fooleries to abuse me

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who was the other.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: She was your fair Niece sir Paul; the most disconsolate Beauty that ere I saw, giving herself for ever lost unto your love sir Phillip, presuming you once promised her Marriage, of which she made a claim this Morning by her Nurse, whom you reviled by name of Bawd, calling fair Constance Whore; and to her more despite, hastened your Marriage sooner by a day, than you before intended with this Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Constance! May that name in all other women be accursed beyond themselves. Hell itself could not have vapoured such an error forth, as I am lost in. Constance! why was that name made here, that Saint-like Maids, when it brought to my mind a Devils, nay worse, a Whores? to whom before it was given.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Sir Phillip, and Madam, you apprehend these things as things done, when they are not things indeed, but as it were show and devise, as by the sequel you may at large apprehend.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I am of your mind Master Bullfinch. And trust me I am glad my Niece was drawn into the witty conceit. For which with a new Gown I will thank her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Where is she? I will endure no longer till I see her.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: The Masquers are all gone sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Gone Villain.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: They took their Coaches instantly, and dispersed themselves by several ways, I had no Commission to stay them.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Are you so sensible of her loss?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: My Niece might notwithstanding her lost love have taken me home in her Coach.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You shall have mine sir Paul and my company so far to see her; and whether their presentation were jest or earnest, I will not rest till I be satisfied; My Coach. I will make no stay Sweetheart. She is gone.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Excellent! the Bride is stolen to bed.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: It should be so. I like the custom well.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: For if you apprehend it rightly, it expresseth duty in the Woman to lie prepared for him; and love in the Man, not to be slack to embrace that duty.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A pretty Moral! A Woman's duty to lie down, and a Man's love to get up. One may learn something of these old fellows every day.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Therefore no Coach, no Company noble Knight. Pursue your home occasions, and God give ye joy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay sir Paul. I protest.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Not a word more of it directly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Take me with you good sir Paul to see your Niece. I find Master Nonsense here very indifferent. And I know it will be the greater joy to her to match but into the family of sir Phillip, of which I am a half Pillar now. Besides my sister made me half a promise of her in good faith, my Governors my Witness, and I have loved her ever since.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: But you never saw her face.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, but I will be hanged if I did not love her Visor the best erewhile, though I could not tell whose it was, nor which was which.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Good Master Water Widgine, this is no time of night to dive into business of this depth. It is Nestling time I take it. How think you Master Bullfinch.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I apprehend it to be past twelve a Clock very near.

sp.speaker: Squ.
Bull.
sp.p: I apprehend you sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: We will, see you to the Gate by your leave

div2.stage: Ex Omnes. The End of the second Act.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What has she written here? It is the same hand I read in the Morning. I am not your counterfeit, or unchaste Constance: But that only Constance, that truly love you, and that will, if you live not for me, die for you. O that I could at any price or penance now redeem one day! Never was hasty Match sooner repented.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: He is melancholy methinks. 'slid my sister may lie long enough languishing for a Ladyship, if this fit hold him: for she has it not really till he go to bed and dub her.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Will you not go to bed sir? we wait for your points.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will. But is it time? Brother, would you would do me the favour to inquire.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yes, I will go see for the Possets sake.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Captain, deal fairly with me. By what means joined you with this society? or how grew so soon your trust or great acquaintance with them?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Without offence I will tell you. You know this Morning at your Lodging, there past some words betwixt me, and your sullen Kinsman, Master indeed la, Tridewell, and from him too much indeed for me, a professed Soldier to bear: But the place protected him. Till after upon mature consideration I made after him for satisfaction, thus
armed as you see. Purposing with this Ropes end to right me; and to maintain that right with this sword, which I thank Mars never yet failed me; as it hath well been manifested by the effusion of much unworthy blood of my abusers, in France, Spain, Italy, Poland, Sweden, Hungary, all parts of Germany.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Good Captain travel not so far in your relation: but come home again to the business.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I have used it in some score or two of Sea fights too by the way.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But to the matter Captain; where met you my Cousin?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The first sight I recovered of him, was as he was entering the house of the greasy Knight there, what call you him?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir Paul Squelch?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Squelch, Aye a pox squelch him. I waited a quarter of an hour at his door, for your Kinsman; and longer I would not, had he been Kinsman to the Emperor, and my Enemy. Therefore in I went, told Master Tridewell in his ear, my coming was to call him forth, to discharge the office of a Gentleman with his Sword, in answering those wrongs wherewith I held my reputation wounded. Was it not well, ha? Could a poor Gentleman say more? and that in civil fashion very privately in respect of the company, not showing any the least distemper, in look or gesture. But the Women read presently in his countenance the whole matter; and briefly by their pretty persuasion I took ordinary satisfaction of him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What was that Captain?

sp.speaker: An
sp.p: Why he confessed he wronged me, was sorry for it, and so forth. What should we speak more on it. This you must not speak of neither. You must promise me that on your honour, as you desire to hear what follows: I love no ripping up old soars.

sp.speaker: Luc,
sp.p: Not a word I, Captain upon my word. What a Rascals this! to the point good Captain.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Then thus sir? I soon perceived, their drift to appease,
and win me to their friendship was for my assistance, and indeed to bear them out in this nights work, the Mask. The whole plot of all which was merely to sow dissension between you and your new married Lady, to work if they can a separation, before carnal copulation, In which if they can prevail, and that the dislike continue between you to that height, that a divorce be required equally by the consent of you both, your Marriage then is frustrated, and you stand in statu quo prius do ye hear. So your Cousin Tridewell may lawfully pursue his hopes in your Bride, who he loves as eagerly as the melancholy virgin dotes on you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But may this hold good in Law Captain?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: There is a Canon for it Sir. If both parties agree to a divorce after Marriage, so it be before Copulation.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Though the former part of his discourse, was a most egregious lie, yet the last hath some sound of pleasure in it: which I may make use of.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Come give me the instrument. Shall I never find thee any where, but thou wilt by just desert exact a beating from me? Hast thou no conscience? wouldst thou have me lame myself, or melt my grease upon thee. Come Sir, I have overheard you all; give me the Instrument, the instrument I say. Indeed I will have it. So. Now Sir

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay Cousin, for the service he hath done you tonight, and love of me, pardon him this time. Besides, his charge is in the house, at whose charge he lives. You will both shame and undo him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Well Sir, I shall for this time pardon you, and never beat you more, if before Sir Phillip here you will subscribe to this. It is nothing but a faithful protestation to do reasonable things as I shall appoint, and not to reveal what I shall trust you withal.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: If you will covenant on your part in defence of my reputation, to let me rail at you behind your back, I will subscribe,

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p:
Take your pleasure. I am content. Write Sir. In what without a Knave we cannot end,
A Knave employed does the office of a friend.

sp.speaker: An.
