sp.p: Here Sir, I deliver it as my deed.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Here, and I deliver you this again to keep. Indeed you shall for performance of covenants.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O Sir you are defeated. My sister hath fortified her lodging with locks, bolts, bars, and barricados.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To what end brother: for what cause?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I know not whither it be discontent or wilfulness, that possesses her: but you are to have no entrance there tonight. That she has sufficiently sworn.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How! am I denied? To my wish.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Pray let me speak with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: At large you shall. For though it be my wedding night you shall be my Bedfellow. Lights there. Good night brother.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Good night Captain.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now Governor? what has angered thee? something troubles thy countenance.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Your coming, and the privilege of this place hath once more preserved that unworthy Tridewell from the justice of my fury, which should have fallen on him, had he been twinned with me by this light.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By this light, Governor? would you have fought by Candlelight.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir I dare do it by day light, Moonlight, Star-light.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Owl-light.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Any light under the Sun. And that shall be tried well on Tridewels head, dee hear?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A good jest! Tried well upon Tridewell. He has wit in his anger. But Governor, laying your anger aside, let me be beholden to your wit in achieving this Northern Lass. Thy acquaintance with her must be the means. Prithee go lie with me, and help me to dream out some course. Nay look now thy fury blows so high thou dost not hear me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Not hear? yes, were I in a Combat as great as ever I myself fought any, I could both hear, and give counsel. Therefore say unto yourself, by the help of your
Governor she is your own.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O Man past example!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: But dee hear?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Here, here. Thou shalt have anything gives him Money.

div2.stage: Sce. II. Enter Squelch, Constance, Nonsence, Trainewell.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Come your ways housewife. No more of your whinings, and counterfeit tricks. If this Gentleman be not worthy of your love, I am not worthy to be your Uncle, directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Alas, what mean you sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Accept of him, you accept of me. If you refuse him you deny me directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: She understands you not a word sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: If you will join hands and faith with him, Here is your portion, there is your Jointure; if not, your way lies before you, pack directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Good sir, consider her disease. If her understanding were direct, you might speak directly to her. But if I have any discretion she is too full of melancholy to be purged this way.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: What would you have me do? Or how in your discretion would you council me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Not to be mad sir, because she is melancholy, not by taking a wrong course for her recovery to ruin her, and forfeit your judgment Do you think, that commands with chidings, threats, or stripes have power to work upon her, when she has neither will nor reason within herself to do, or not to do anything whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now the gigs up.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: If her health in sense and understanding were perfect: yet as she is Woman, her will were first to be wrought upon by fair and gentle treaty. But as she is at this time so sick in mind, that knowledge of what she is, what she does, especially of what she should do is dead in her, her Mind must be first recovered; and that by a due course, in soft and temperate proceedings; to which fit time as well as means must be allowed. Moreover

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: O. No moreover I beseech you, nor more of her at this time. I understand your purpose already. I do directly. Therefore speedily take what course, and use what means shall in your discretion be thought fit. I will subscribe, I will directly subscribe to your discretion. My wife when she went out of the world left me as great a curse behind her in the charge she gave me with this Woman, this quick sighted Guide of my house, a blind one were better.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You should first see, if it pleased you, how her affection may be wrought upon by the Gentleman's own fair entreaty. Pray sir speak to her like a Suitor, look upon him Sweetheart: This Gentleman loves you. Pray speak sir. Do you not?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Never credit me pretty Gentlewoman

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nor will I, fear it not. Nor any man that says he loves me. For alas I was too lately scorned.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: You are a Lass indeed. I protest and vow, and such a one, as I would be very sorry to appear any way, or in the least degree, as it were please you to understand me: for I will be sworn, there is not in the World.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Truth in swearing, less in promising.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: If you will believe me Lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nor no man for your sake.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: There is not in the world I say

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I say so too sir. What was it I pray.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: There is not in the world any Gentlewoman

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Tell that no further; for we are all too gentle lessen men were less cruel.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Hear him speak Constance.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You shall hear me sing first by your leave.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Poor heart.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Here is wise work! direct Lunacy and Idiotism. Bless my house from the Ward Masters Informers,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Pray sir, are you sir Phillip?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Say you are.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Yes Lady, I am sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: But you are none of my Sparrow. Your mouth is not wide enough for your words.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: She has stopped his mouth there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: His words would soften Adamantine ears. And looks would melt a Marble heart to tears. O woe is me!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Nay you must not weep Sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: What mun I do then? Shall I ever get him by singing trow ye? In troth I would never but sing, if I thought that were the gainest way.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I had rather hear you sing though, then see you weep.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: It must be of my Love then, my Sparrow as I told you. And thus it goes.

A bonny bonny Bird I had A bird that was my Marrow: A bird whose pastime made me glad, And Phillip it was my Sparrow. A pretty Playfere: Chirp it would, And hop, and fly to fist, Keep cut, as it were a Usurers Gold, And bill me when I list. Phillip, Phillip, Phillip it cries But he is fled and my Joy dies. But were my Phillip come again, I would not change my Love For Juno's bird with gaudy train, Nor yet for Venus Dove. Nay, would my Phillip come again, I would not change my state, For his great Name sakes wealth of Spain, To be another's Mate. Phillip Phillip, etc. No no, you cannot be the Man. I know him right well by you sir, as wily as you be. Gin you had all his trim gear upon you, and all his sweets about you, yet I should not be so fond to mistake a jenny Owlet for a Tassel Gentle. Ah, ah, ha.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Why Love, what fault do you find in this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Faith, but even ean. That he is not sir Phillip. For thus would he do. Thus would he kiss his hand; and thus take me by mine. Thus would he look, and set his eye on mine: And give me leave to see myself in his eyes. It was the
best Glass in troth that ever I saw. I ne'er look well fine. Nor ever shall I am sure, until I see me there again.
But he is gone, alas he is gone, and all too late I sorrow: For I shall never be well again, till yesterday be tomorrow. God you good Even sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Follow her sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And put her to it sir, and out of this humour. I will add the the other five hundred to her portion, and you bring her about handsomely. O when I was a Bachelor! I think I can do somewhat yet in my old days. But when I was a Bachelor, how I could have handled this gear.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Never credit me sir, if you will believe me but

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I do believe you sir sufficiently good Master Nonsense. No more of your impertinent speeches. But follow her, and put her to it I say, to it directly. Take her into the Orchard; it was there she fell in love they say. It may be the place is Ominous.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, there will be no way for her recovery, but to remove her lodging, and have some good Physicians about her.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Where you please, and use whose help you please: she is your own; dispose of her freely, as I will of what is mine. I will take a new course of life directly. Let me see. She is lost, past recovery. Say I should marry. I might yet have an heir of mine own.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes, but of whose getting sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: There might rise a fearful question.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Think not of it sir. A man of your years, and gravity, with the respect the World gives you for your place and worship in the Common Wealth, together with the riches you have piled up in a Mountainous estate; to cast all down with yourself, and fortune at the foot of a stranger! Think what would be thought of you, if such a dotage should possess you

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: She is falling into a tedious Lecture.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Pray how was Master Spartledirt talked on the other day for doing such a trick? yet he was held a wise Lawyer. You see a fair example in the late Marriage of sir Phillip Luckless, and his Fitchow, a Match of your own making, and cause of your Nieces and your own Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: No more I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: There is tugging for a Mastery, and buffeting for the breeches. He barks at her, she snaps at him; she breaks his wine Glass, he her looking Glass; she puts away his Servants, he turns away hers; she locks her Chamber door, he bolts his, begetting nothing but a World of strife and disorder.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I pray shut up that point, I will not marry. No directly I will not, though the truth is my purpose: was to have cast myself and fortune wholly upon you, if it might hove seemed well in your discretion, vmh vmh.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I pray stay a little sir, take me along with you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Not a step further, this way by your leave. I think I have puzzled her discretion.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Understand me sir. As I would not have you fall rashly upon anything; no more would I have you fly suddenly from any purpose, without advise and sober deliberation. If you should marry one that would be a Comfortable Nurse unto you, as (though I say it) you partly know

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Say you nothing, for I do know nothing, nor I will know nothing more of this matter directly: For if ever I marry, let me suffer all that the Law provides for Perjury; let me be cropped and slit worse than a French Curtal, or a parliamental delinquent for blaspheming the blood royal. No, I will now bestow my wealth in Monumental good deeds, and charitable uses in my life time, to be talked well on when I am dead.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes, build Alms houses and Hospitals for beggars, and provide in Bridewell, and houses of Correction for your friends and kindred. Pray give enough to Bedlam, you may feel some part of that benefit yourself before you die, if these fits hold you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: She would have me do no good with that I have neither. Let me consider. The most I have to say directly hath not been very well gotten. Were it not a point of good conscience, to spend that prodigally, and save a lewd Heir the sin? And that which I have got well and honestly, hath been with much care and travel; were it not then a point of equity to myself, to spend that with ease and pleasure? It is done directly, what I have is mine own; and I will be merry with it. Within there ho.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: What is the toy now?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sirrah. Take there twenty pieces. Bestow it all presently in choicest meats, and richest Wines for my Supper. This one nights Supper directly. What I have is mine own: and I will be merry with it.

sp.speaker: Tra. Cle.
sp.p: Bless us!

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Six brace of Partridges, and six Pheasants in a Dish. Godvvits, Knots, Quails, and the rest of the meats answerable for half a score, or a dozen persons of the best quality: whom I will think of presently.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Brain of a down right Justice! What means my Master, to leap out of thirty shillings a Week house keeping into twenty pounds a Supper? I may sell my Clerks place: for sure he means to thrust himself out of the Commission. He can be no Justice long if this humour hold. Who shall be the Guests trow?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I have it directly. You shall go to the Ordinaries, and from thence invite such young Gallants as you find to be Gamesters. I mean of the highest cut.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Men that you do not know sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Aye directly. If they know me, or have heard of me it is sufficient: we shall be soon acquainted. Bring not a man with any paid for gold Lace or Scarlet about him, I charge you, nor without a Protection in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You run a great hazard in this sir. You may perhaps be cheated of all you have, if I have any discretion.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And much good do it their good hearts. What I have is mine own, and I will be merry with it directly. You have put me by one or two courses: But not all your discretion shall beat me out of this. If you take some care in the business, and housewife the entertainment to make it brave for my credit, you may get a Gown or a Jewel by it. If not

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir I will obey you. If he be mad I will not be foolish, but strike in for a share. And for your Guests sir, let me alone. My man is best acquainted at the Ordinaries.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Why now you speak.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Within there. Beauis. But in troth sir, I doubt whither any such Guests will come, you have always been so strict and terrible in your justiciary courses.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Let him say mine eyes are opened, and their virtue is revealed
unto me. And if any of the youngsters have Mistresses, let them bring them. They shall have Music; what I have is mine own, and I will be merry with it. My flesh, though not in the way of Marriage, requires some satisfaction too. Where might a man in all this plentiful Town, find a choice piece directly that he might make his own? only his own? A very hard question. And custom has made it almost an unreasonable one, though it were in ones own Wife. In a Citizens or Tradesman's Wife; a Man must suffer the Rivalship of a slovenly husband: the stink of his horns ever under ones nose. A cast Lady, or Gentlewoman of courtly acquaintance, to maintain her, is to feed a Fountain, that wastes itself through many Spouts: what I supply her with, will be drawn out by twenty. All her friends must share of my prodigality. To train up an innocent country Girl, is like hatching a Cuckoo; as soon as she is ripe, and sees the world afore her, she flies at her advantage, and leaves me dead in the nest. How now.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Delinquent brought before your worship to be examined, a Gentlewoman sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Who brings her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Vexhem the Constable sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Look on his feet. Sure it is the Devil in his likeness: That old Bawd knowing how it stood with me, has brought me one of his succubae Art. Sure it is Vexhem?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sure sir? The devil himself knows him not better than I know him from the Devil. I am sure, he has been in fee with me these nine years: almost ever since he was Constable; and has brought more profit to my desk than all the honest Officers in the counties of your Commission sir. O he is a rare fellow, he will tickle a Whore in Cony.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: You know my mind. I will in and handle this gear in privity.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Beauis, You understand me. Prithee go discreetly about it.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Pray let me see a little of this first.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: If I put her to it or ever offer to put any Woman to it again, never credit me: let me never be trusted, I protest and vow Gentlewoman she has used me

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Very ill favouredly methinks.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Have you put her to it sir.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I cannot put her to it, nor she will not be put to it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I would not go to it, nor I mun not go to it, For love, nor yet for fee: For I am a Maid, and will be a Maid, And a good one till I die. Yet mine intent, I could repent, for an man's company. But you are not he Sir. If you be, you are wondrously changed. I am sure his faults were not written on his forehead. God pardon him.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: If mine be, you can best read them, it is your own handwriting.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: She has done a cure on him. He spoke sense now. Alas Sir, that a fair hand should make such blots! what hand is it? Secretary, Roman, Court, or Text? I have not seen the like: it is all Dominical letters, red Ink. His face is like an Almanac of all Holidays.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sure it is Stenography, every Character a word: and here and there one for a whole sentence.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Here is one might serve for a whole History. The life and death of Raw head, and Bloody bones.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I see I am not such an Ass, I would I might never stir but I am Where is Sir Paul? If I do not tell him

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: What did you to provoke her thus?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Nothing but what I can answer in a sort dee see me as well as never give me credit I had warrant under his hand

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: By word of mouth sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: That is above hand by your leave.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Is it so? Good Sir, his meaning was, you should put her fairly on like a Lover, with sweet speeches, and gentle behaviour.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: She understands nothing that I can speak.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Nor anybody else I think.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: And therefore you fell to express yourself in rude action. She has served you but well: you are a fine putter to it indeed.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Mun toot Mun toot, Muntara ra ra Muntara ra ra ra ree,
And ever I sigh and cry alack for Phillips love I die. Just so did our Dairy Maid at home serve my Lady Fidledees Butler. And there I learnt it. But when she had so done what did she then do? Bestowed a pennyworth of Unguentum Album, and it made him whole presently. Good Mistress. Traynwell send to your Apothecary for some: it will make him well even now.

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.p: Aye sweetheart: but first you shall go in the Coach with me to the Doctors.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.p: I know I am not well too. But I will have no Doctor but Sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: It shall be Sir Phillip, (poor soul,) all must be Sir Phillip. You shall lie at his house.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: But not with him by my faith, and your leave, in it we be married. Prithee Beauis gar him wash his face, he will scare some bodies Barnes else.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I will throw him into the Dock rather than he shall succeed Jack Of Dandy. Come sir, all shall be well again. Fear not.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

div2.stage: Sce. III. Enter Lucklesse and Tridewell.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Cousin, I understand you at full. And am glad that occasion hath pointed out a probability to lead me out of this labyrinth; and you to your desired end.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Follow but the way you are in Sir, and you shall arrive at your own wishes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She has put me into it herself too.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: By sequestering herself from you the first night.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: For which Cousin, if I take not occasion to keep myself from her, all nights, days, and times hereafter, may the act of our bodies beget prodigious monsters and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: A fearful vow! look to it. And I warrant she sues for the Divorce first.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
May we prove but as certain as you are confident in our other project, for recalling Constance to herself, and me
then to her, these fetters being shaken off, may they prove golden ones to you, I shall not envy you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: For her take no thought sir. The interest I have in her Tutoress, with the work I have fashioned upon my Anvil, shall bring all to your wish. I expect to hear from him instantly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will freely resign your wish to you, and add half I have to augment her estate to you. O I tremble to think on her: her presence shakes the house like an earthquake: the outrage of Prentices is not so terrible to a Bawd or a Cutpurse, as her voice is to me. Yet to you she may be calm as the breath of friendship, and mild as the midnight whispers of chaste love.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sir, I profess my affection flies eagerly at her. She takes me deeply, how ever you have mistaken one another. O here comes my Anvil! Methinks his very countenance invites me to strike him, though I know he does me good service now.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: It is done sir. I warrant she is placed, successfully, dee hear?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: How prithee?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I have sent her before his Worship by a Constable.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who has he sent? before whose Worship?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You shall know all. He has sent your cast whore before sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The Mystery, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: The success shall unfold it in good time to your and my benefit? doubt not, if she but follow her instructions.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, if she be not Mistress of her Art, there is no deceit among Tradesmen, no bribery among Officers, no bankrupt out of Ludgate, nor Whore out of Bridewell.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And if I have not fitted her with a Second, my friend vex hem, the Constable, then say there is no wit among Knaves, no want among Scholars, no rest in the grave, nor unquietness in Marriage, dee hear?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Of which here comes the truest testimony.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Out of my doors thou Miscreant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay sister. O governor, art here.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
Avoid my house, and that presently, I will claw your skin
off after your Livery else, and make you so much nakeder than time makes all other serving Creatures.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do you talk of turning away my Man? You shall give me leave to turn away your Howdee first, and then put off my, God a mercy how dost thou.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Am I jeered? flouted to my face? Is this fit usage for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A Wife? a Witch.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: A Husband? a Hangman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Out puss.

sp.speaker: Trid.
sp.p: Nay sir, indeed the fault is yours most extremely now. Pray sir forbear to strain beyond a Woman's patience.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Am I scorned and reviled?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Made a property for laughter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Have I no friend, no Servant to command?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Has my Ladyship made me so lamentable a thing, that I have lost the power of a Mistress? You sir, run and call some friends to succour me, or I will throttle you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Stir but a foot sirrah, or utter but a syllable, and I will cut your throttle pipe.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I shall be carved out betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: What will become of me? you, Woodcock, Nini-hammer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Have you forgot my name sister? would not Widgine become your mouth, as well? forget your natural brothers name?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Can you call me sister, and see me abused thus?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Foutre for sisters; I am not to meddle with an other man's Wife. I am about one for myself. You mentioned her first to me. But I must be beholden to others wits and means to compass her: or else

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do as I bid you, or

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O sir she will rend me in pieces, tear me like a Lark.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Dost thou fear her or me. Do it or I

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir, there is Master Walter can sing it rarely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So he shall sir, and so will all; but you must put us in. Begin.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Hey down down, etc.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister, Wife, and all, is a present nothing to this. Come round Gentlemen. Keep her but off, and let me alone.

div2.stage:
They all take hands, and dance round. VVidgine in the midst sings this Song. They all beare the burden, while shee scolds and striues to be amongst 'hem. Tridewell holds her off.
Song.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: He that marries a Scold, a Scold, He has most cause to be merry: For when she is in her fits, he may cherish his wits By singing hey down derry.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hey down down derry down down down, etc.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Gallants. I apprehend you would be private.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O no Master Bullfinch, you shall make one of our Council.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I apprehend Gentlemen you are merrily disposed, in good sadness.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Apprehend a fools head. Come into play.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Aye, Aye in with him, and about again.

div2.stage: They pull him into the Round.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: He that marries a merry Lass, He has most cause to be sad: For let her go free in her merry tricks, she Will work his Patience mad. But he that marries a Scold a Scold, etc. He that weds with a Roaring Girl, that will both scratch and bite; Though he study all day to make her away, will be glad to please her at night. And he that copes with a sullen Wench, That scarce will speak at all. Her doggedness more than a Scold or a Whore, Will perpetrate his Gall.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p:
Hey down down, etc. He that is matched with a Turtle Dove,
That has no spleen about her, Shall waste so much life in the love of his wife, He were better be without her.
But he that marries a Scold, a Scold, etc.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: O scorn upon scorn, torment upon torment. Let me rather be buried alive than bear this.
Slaves, Rascals, get ye all out of my doors. By virtue of my nails, I charge ye. I will not leave an Eye or a Nose amongst ye.

sp.speaker: How. Wid. Bull. Anv.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come bouncing after my boys.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: O how am I wronged.

div2.stage: Ex. Omnes preter Fit. Tri. Bull.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Sure I did apprehend this mirth, as right as could be possible the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Trid.
sp.p: Madam, I see too much of your vexation; and indeed I suffer too much with you. As I am a Gentleman I will give you right friendly Council, if you will hear me.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sir I have perceived humanity in you and do love it in you. But I know not what to do, nor whom to hear. I am fallen into the pit of bondage, and will take any course for my Redemption. O Master Bullfinch.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: This will make to my purpose.

sp.speaker: Fir.
sp.p: Sir I am wronged beyond expression. This Gentleman is an eye witness of my sufferings. Pray come in Sir. I will hear your counsel together with this Gentleman's advise.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Madam, your case is in my apprehension, most desperate, yet full of comfort in regard you seek advise and counsel. Mine is ever ready, and more fortunate oftentimes the judicious. For I do nothing but upon good reason and deliberation.

div2.stage: The end of the third Act.
Act. IIII. Sce. I. Enter Squelch. Holdup. Vexhem.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Sir I beseech your worship, deal not so severely with me.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sirrah I will teach you how to deal with Dealers, and not with virtuous Gentlewomen; bring Innocency before Justice; and be able to lay nothing to her charge.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Indeed sir, the Captain informed me of her; and said he would be here ready to accuse her. Good sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Most officious Sir. What warrant had you? None. What is the Captains name? you know not. Where is his lodging? you are ignorant. But here was your cunning; it appears most plainly, that you thinking her to be one of the trade, thought to make a Prey of her purse: which since your affrightment, could not make her open unto you, you thought to make her Innocency smart for it. I will make your Knavery smart for it directly. Come is the Mittimus ready? give me it

div2.stage: Writes and seales it. Ent. Cleark.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Good your worship, hold your hand. For my poor family sake.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Here take him forth, and let the next Constable convey him to Newgate.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Sir it is the first time that ever I offended in this kind. I pray your worship be of a better mind towards me.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Away I say directly. As I am in my right Mind and Middlesex, I will show my justice on thee.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Does the Knave laugh? Bring him back. May a man ask the cause of your Mirth?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Sir I have laughed at the vexation of a thousand in my days. I hope I may have leave once in my life to laugh at mine own.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: O is it so? Pray hold you merry sir.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now Lady, whereas you were brought before me as a Delinquent, I retain you as my Mistress. I like her beyond measure. A pretty young thing! new brought to a pace! Ah, ha! She has committed a little Country folly, as she privately confesses. What is that? It may stand in rank with that they call virtue here; and then she is content to live as privately as I please. She shall up, I will winter and summer her before she shall see a high way of this Town. She is for my turn directly. Mistress Holdup, is your name say you?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
Camitha Holdup sir. A poor Gentlewoman. My father
bore the office of a Commissioner for the peace in the West country, till Misfortune wrought his estate out of his hands.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Holdup! I have heard of him, and know what it was that sunk him. He lived by the Seaside; it was trading with the Pirates. Buying their goods, and selling them victuals;

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: It is too true sir. He paid so dearly for it at last, that I have no more, but my bare breeding, and what I bear about me to live upon.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Which is enough: enough directly; if you can bear yourself discreetly, and contain yourself within those bounds of Fortune, in which I will plant you. Alas good soul, weep not; let Money and Authority be thy comfort. By which thou shalt feel no want, nor fear no danger. But to our business. I have already acquainted you with my Niece Constances disease, and that she is removed out of my house for her health. I will lodge you at a trusty Tenants house where she is unknown. You shall take her name upon you.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Which is mine own already.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And if you can but a little counterfeit her Melancholy, you may freely pass for her; and my accesses to thee, my sweet Girl, shall crown us with fulness of delight and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Sir, you have most worthily made me your own; and all my study shall be to obey you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now had I but a fit attendant for the person of my love!

sp.speaker: Hold..
sp.p: Some simple honest body sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Then we were fitted. How now.

sp.speaker: Clea..
sp.p: My Lady Luckless man desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: Stand you by unseen a while. Send him in. I do expect some Message now, in the behalf of her unlucky Ladyships wise brother, Master Widgine, touching my Niece. Now friend how does my good Lady?

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: I left her very ill sir; for she has beaten me, and thrust me out of doors with her own hands, without penny in my purse, or other Cloak on my back, than the bare Livery, that a cast Serving-man cannot shake off, of Knave and Beggar.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: Thou leftest her very ill indeed. But well, thou wouldst have me be a means to reestablish thee in thy Lady.

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: In her service sir.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: I speak by a figure Humfrey: for to be inward with, or indeed within a Mistress, is to be a servant in the most Courtly phrase.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Aye sir. Those are convenient Servants sir. We are covenant servants. They are respected above husbands: We abased beneath slaves. They purchase place, honours, and offices oftentimes with their Ladies monies, when we find not our wages without hard words, and are in fear, (poor snakes) to have our sloughs pulled over our ears before the year go about. We drudge for our Ladies, they play with their Ladies: But the best is, we labour and sweat it out for our Ladies, when they are feign to take Physic, and lie in for their Ladies.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: Most intelligent Humfrey. Let us retire to the purpose. Put case I have a Mistress in store for you; to whom I may commend you upon my own credit, and undertake for your entertainment and means by my own purse. What would you say? what would you do?

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: Sir, I will say over the Gent. ushers Grammar to you, and do her service by the rules.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: Well said directly. Incipe Humfride. Say your part.

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: In a Gentleman Usher there be eight parts. Boldness, Neatness, Flattery and Secrecy, rewarded. Diligence, Obedience, Truth and Honesty, unrewarded.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: What is his Boldness.

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: His Boldness is the use of his Manhood in right of his Ladies honour, degree, place or privilege, at home, abroad, in private or public meeting, for the hand, for the wall, for the what she will, for the what she calls.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: How is it rewarded?

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: By obtaining of Suits made out of cast Gowns or Petticoats. Which if he be a Taylor, as most of our middle sort of Professors are, he is thereby made a Man in spite of the proverb, and thrust into the high way of advancement.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: Perge Humfrey. His neatness now?

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p:
His neatness consists most diversely sir. Not only in the decent wearing of those clothes and clean linen, pruning his hair, ruffling his Boots, or ordering his shoe ties; these are poor expressions, a Journeyman Barber will do it. But to
do his office neatly, his garb, his pace, his postures, his comes on and his comes off, his complements, his visits.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: His Howdees.

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: In which a profound judgment would be puzzled.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: I believe thee.

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: And the most absolute or artificial memory set of the rack. To be able to relate how this Ladies tooth does; and the other Ladies toe. How this Ladies Milk does: and how the others Doctor liked her last water: how this Ladies husband; and how the other Ladies dog slept last night: how this child, that Monkey, this Nurse, that Parrot, and a thousand such. Then his neatness in Chamber work, or about the person of his Lady, in case her Maid or her Woman be otherwise occupied, to convey a pin into her ruff neatly, or add a help to her head dressing, as well as Iohn among the Maids. Lastly, his dexterity in Carving, and his discretion in Marshaling of meats; to give every mess the due service, and every dish his lawful pre-eminence.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: And how is this neatness rewarded Humfrey?

sp.speaker: Hum..
sp.p: Doubly sir: at board and at bed: by good bits, and the love of the Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: Well Humfrey, because we will not make this scene too long, we will omit the rest: only why are your last four parts, Diligence, Obedience, Truth and Honesty unrewarded?

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: Sir. They are parts that spring out of virtue, and are therefore born with their reward in their mouths, and ought to expect no further from any service in these times.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: Most edifying Humfrey. I have a Mistress in store for thee.

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: I long to see her sir.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: Didst thou never see my Niece Constance?

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: No sir. But I have heard she is diseased with Melancholy; and if she should prove mad too, like my old Lady, I were then as far to seek as ever I was.

sp.speaker: Squ..
sp.p: Fear it not Humfrey. My warrant ease thy care. Niece come forth.
I shall fit you with a servant. Fall to your Postures Humfrey. Your Garb.

So. Your Pace. So. Your Conge. So. Hand your Lady. Good. Arm your Lady. Good still. Side your Lady. Very good. Draw out your Lady. Excellent. Present
your Lady. Singular well, good Humfrey.

sp.speaker: How..
sp.p: Sir, I can Shoulder my Lady too: but that is when she takes Coach; and Foot my Lady, when she alights.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Precious Humfrey, I admire thy Art.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I learnt all of a good old Ladies man in the Strand sir, that must be nameless.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now Humfrey, Walk your Lady to the Burse.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O most Hostlerly spoken! Under correction sir, Wait your Lady I pray sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well said Humfrey. Here is something for my instruction. Now wait your Lady to the Burse. She has some trifles to buy there. I will find you there presently, and conduct you to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: What shall I do with all this sir? I would indeed but buy an ounce or two of thread, some Netting pins and Needles, and a Frame to flourish my work on. Hereafter I will work in gold and silver, if you please, for your own wearing.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: As I would wish! her simplicity takes me above her beauty. Go I say. I will follow. Methinks I even feel myself, thank myself for being in this good humour. What I have is mine own, and I will be merry with it directly.

div2.stage: Sce. II. Enter Fitchow, Tridewell, Bulfinch, Widgine, Anvile.

sp.speaker: Fitc.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you now know the calamity I suffer under. And you have showed me the best way to comfort: for which I thank you. I have given you my resolution for a Divorce, upon condition. Before which, I must promise you nothing sir. But I assure you in the mean time, you stand prime in my affection: for I have in all found you a right worthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Madam, I have not utterance to declare my acceptance of your love. It must therefore be locked up in my breast, the treasure of my heart. Now for the condition upon which your Divorce depends, we must see that performed, and then

sp.speaker: Fitc.
sp.p: Sir, I will make good more than I now may promise.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You speak nobly.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: It relishes a little too much of womanly wilfulness I confess. But all my wilfulness (that I will promise you sir) shall die in the end of this business.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Well then, before your discreet neighbour Master. Bullfinch here. If you have not your will in this, I will disclaim in your favour hereafter. Sir, the condition is (as you may remember

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend it Sir. That sir Paul Squelch his Niece be first married or contracted, and then she consents to a divorce: And that you be assistant to her brother here to obtain her for him.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: To which I promise my ready help, only I must not appear in the business.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I will only appear in it, for I will not be seen in the matter.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: As how sir?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: As thus sir. I will keep your counsel: not only in holding my peace to all the world, but in saying nothing to sir Paul himself. Dee apprehend me sir?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And thank you sir. Now every man to his part Master. Widgine, You have both your sisters and my best directions already, which I doubt not but with the help of your Governor you will make good use of. Madam will you in, and but wish well to our proceedings, and trouble your thoughts no further.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, what help he has of me, is for the Ladies and his own sake, not yours dee hear.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No blustering now good Governor: Prithee restrain thy fury. Thou canst never hear nor speak to that Gent with any patience; and yet he is on our side now. Prithee let us lose no time. I never longed more for my mothers coming from a Christening, than to be at this Northern Lass.

div2.stage: Sce. III. Enter Tridewell, Trainewell, Holdup.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Wanton, you have begun propitiously: Proceed but confidently, and I will warrant thee a wealthy husband by it, or a composition that may prove the better purchase.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Sir, be you and this Lady but as confident of my fidelity,
and trust me in this action, and if I break not the toils your Kinsman is in, and make you Mistress of my Interest in sir Paul, let all the good you intended me, be a lockram Coif, a blue Gown, a Wheel and a clean Whip. You are sure the Lady will yield to a Divorce, if Constance whom I now personate be first married or contracted.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Right. She does but hold off till then, and that wilfully; because she fears it is for Constances love only, that her Husband desires the Divorce.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And you are sure that Constance is safe from her discovery.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Aye upon the hazard of my discretion.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: To any then that knows her not very well, If I appear not the same Constance you have given me her Character right?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: The best that we can possibly.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay, I have a further help then, you both imagine yet.

sp.speaker: Tri. Tra.
sp.p: May we know it.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: It shall be no secret. My Servant Howdee, whom you and sir Paul, suppose his Lady turned away, was by her Ladyship taught only to feign it; and cunningly instructed to work himself into the service of Constance, to further her brothers proceedings. And since fortune has put him upon me, whom he takes to be the same Mistress, if I make not apt use of it

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: It is most fairly ominous. Come Lady. He cannot. but be at hand; and our stay may do hurt. (You remember the Doctors lodging I told you of, and sir Phillips appointment to meet you there an hour hence?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: All sir. I would use no other. She is there already.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: No more then; away. Fare you well sweet Creature.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
If my deceit now, should be discovered, before my work be ended, my Brain-tricks might perhaps, in stead of all these fair hopes, Purchase me the Lash. before Venus, my flesh even trembles to think on it. It brings likewise into my consideration, the baseness of my condition; how much unpitied the punishment of a Whore is, and how suddenly it overtakes her! My joint Conspirators are in no danger. I only run the
hazard, though they are as deep in fact as myself. Well. If I scape this pull, and draw any fortune by it, I will change my function sure. A common Whore? I will be a Nun rather. They come most fitly, and I must into my fit

div2.stage: Sce. IIII. Enter Widgine, Anvile, Howdee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Indeed sir, it was my Ladies plot, but you must take no notice of it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I will thank her with all my heart, and she shall never know on it.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: But if sir Paul, my now Master should discover my deceit, how shall I scape his vengeance.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: What dost thou think of me, weak fellow? Am not I a Commander, ha?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Aye, in the war Captain: but he is a Justice of Peace, and a Commander of Captains in Middlesex, sends two or three drunken Ones to Newgate at a clap sometimes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fear no discovery Humfrey. Let me but see her, and I will warrant thee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: She will see none but sir Phillip, you must be nobody else. Remember that: you must know no other name you have. Now if you can sir Phillip it handsomely there is it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I warrant thee, and my Governor shall sir Phillip me at every word; and if I do not sir Phillip her, better than ever she was Filliped in her life, then say I am no Legitimate Widgine.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: It is past your strength or reach either by forty I believe. I doubt your middle finger is too short Master Widgine.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Well, I must venture it. Here she comes. Has a Baby.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What is she doing. Odds me! making a Baby I think. Are you good at that i'faith? I will be at that sport with you, it shall cost me a fall else.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O she has a hundred such apish toys. Even now she was great with Child forsooth as she could go. And was persuaded she had a Child as big as I in her belly. I wondered at it, and she told me she had had a hundred there as big in her days.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Aye but she knew not what she said. By and by, I must be a man midwife forsooth and deliver her: for it was past all Woman's skill? Now she thinks she is brought a bed, and nurses the Child herself.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And who is the father?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O none but sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I will father it as well as he. Is it a Boy or a Girl trow. Would she would make a Christening Banquet while we are here. Hark she sings.

Peace wayward Barn; O cease thy moan: Thy far more wayward Daddy is gone: And never will recalled be By cries of either thee, or me: For should we cry, until we die, We could not scant his cruelty. Ballow, Ballow, etc.
He needs might in himself foresee, What thou successively mightst be; And could he then, (though me forego) His Infant leave, ere he did know, How like the Dad would be the Lad, In time, to make fond Maidens glad? Ballow, ballow, etc.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How is this pretty Mistress. Constance, that you complain of your Love before he be lost?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Who be you I pray?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray thee tell her Governor. I have not the heart to lie now.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: It is sir Phillip Lady, come to do you right. Dee hear?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Yes sir, I hear you vary well; and could even wish in my heart I could believe you.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Speak yourself sir.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p:
You may Mistress Constance; for as I am an honest man,
I never meant to wrong you.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I do believe you sir. But pray protest no more by that name till you make yourself such by marrying me. You have gotten a barn by me, I is sure of that.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I come for the same purpose Sweetheart. I will both father and keep thy Child, and make thee an honest Woman. Give me your hand before this Gentleman, and your Servant here; and say but the word; I will get a Licence presently, fetch you away, and dispatch you tonight.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Marry me, marry me, quoth the bonny Lass: and when will you begin.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As for thy wedding Lass we will do well enough, in spite of the best of thy Kin.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I can but thank you, obey you, and pray for you sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Governor; wilt thou believe me? It even pities my heart, to wrong so sweet a piece of simplicity. But Fortune has dressed her for me to feed on; and I will fall to.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Or the Devil to choke you. Well boisterous Master Tridewell, your Ropes end hath driven me into a business, here, deserves a whole Rope. But I hope that Destiny attends not me, though this Marriage be his: And since it is his Fate, fair befall it him, I am discharged.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Come Governor, we are agreed; let us go that we may hie us again, and dispatch.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay sir. You shall not say, you married me for naught: you shall hear me sing before you go.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: What an Owsell it is! she means he shall marry her for a Song. Byrlady a competent Modern portion.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
As I was gathering April's flowers, He straight let fall one of his showers; Which drove me to an arbour.
It were better I my Lap had filled. Although the wet my clothes had spilled, Than to have found that harbour For there a subtle Serpent was, Close lying, lurking in the Grass. And there while harmless thinking I,
Still watching when the shower would die, Lay listening to a Bird, That singing sate upon the Bower, Her notes unto the falling shower, the Snake beneath me stirred; And with his sting gave me a clap, that swell my belly not my lap.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By my troth it is pretty.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: And by my conscience it is true, it were made in Durham, on a Lass of my bigness.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: And in thy clothes I believe.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: But will you be gan now, then all my joy leaves me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sweet soul, thou shalt have thy joy again. I will joy thee, enjoy thee, and over joy thee. Governor let us fly about this business. I will not sleep, before I have got a License, stolen her away, wedded her, bedded her, and put her in her wits again.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: Are you able to do that think you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I will warrant thee: for all Maids are mad till they be married.

sp.speaker: Anv.
sp.p: What say you to that: Lady. Pox on you, I run a sweet hazard to advance your fortune, do I not?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Remember your Covenant with Master Tridewell Captain. And when the work is done, here is my hand, you shall partake of what I get by it. And hark you.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: She may perhaps, when she comes to herself, and finds me to be no sir Phillip, be a little startled. But I mean the first night to put so much of my own love into her, as shall work out his I doubt not, or any his that came there before me.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O Gentlemen! my Master is coming, all is spoiled if he take you. Part quickly.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Is mine Uncle come? and mun we part then?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Kiss, and part; kiss and part.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Sweet heart, not a word of me till I come to fetch you off with honour.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: All benisons be with you. Indeed you be the goodliest man, that ever made Maiden feign.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Poor heart she dotes. I do not know how much I am in debt to my conscience, till I have made her amends.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: This may breed good blood. If I come but as well off on my old Uncle, as am like to come on with my young Cousin, here will be a match unlooked for; a match without treaty; a match untalked or unheard of. He is coming before I have shifted my face. Methinks I hear the rustling of his bristles hither. Yet my lips must stand the assault; pray love the Porcupine, leave none of his quills in them.

div2.stage: Sce. V. Enter Squelch to Holdup.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Where is my Girl? My honey sweet Girl? Kiss me; Kiss I say directly: I will secure thee. As I am a Man of Authority, and that of Middlesex, I will secure thee. Ha my Lass, these lips have the true Elixir in them indeed, to restore youth and strength; past all Medeas charms, or what the Poets would have fained. How now! weeps my Love? I hope my Nieces habit has not wrought her disease into thee.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: No: now I see you sir, I am well: perfectly well: yet pardon me sir. Your absence cannot but breed me fears, when I have leisure to think on my unworthy condition, and the danger I undergo in it.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: It was a thousand pities that this Wench was seduced. She might have made a Wife for a good Esquire. She would serve a Tradesman yet, most unblemishably. And when I have done with her, doing that for her, as I mean to do. She may perhaps match with a younger brother, purchase him a place, advance his fortune, to be able in the end to repay her with a Ladyship. It is not without a president; and I will help her to follow the example directly. For what I have is mine own, and I will be merry with it. Ha my bird, my chick! Kiss me. Kiss me up. So. Kiss me up I say. So again. Thou hast done it directly. Maintain it now, with a cordial kiss. So, so, so. Good. Very good; and while it is so, a word with you in private. Come my bird, mh mh mh.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir, there is a woman below.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sir, what have I to do with any woman below: Do you with your woman below. I am very well here.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Is the old man mad trow. Sir, she will have to do with you above, if you speak not with her below. I had much a do to keep her down stairs, her case is so lamentable she says. I never saw a woman so importunate in my life sir. You must down sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I am down already. all is naught. What limb of the devil is it? Dost thou know her?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: She says she is wife to a Constable sir, that you lately committed; and if your Worship. does not release him presently, that he is undone, and she is undone, all their children are undone, that unborn in her belly is undone, and I know not how many more are undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hell take her. How could she know that I was here?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: She spied you in the Street sir, and followed you, and follow you she would, had you gone into the Privy Chamber she swears; her cause enforces her she says. And she is so great with child too, that no man dares give her a thrust to keep her back. I hear her blow up stairs.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Keep her down, I will follow thee

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Good sir be pitiful for the woman's sake, and release him. Perhaps her reckoning is out, and she has nobody to call the Midwife.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I must home to my Clerk then: for I cannot write here; nor do any good besides I am so vexed. But I will return to thee in the evening, Duck: And since I am so apt to be spied, I will come disguised.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Indeed I will put out the Candle when you are here then, for I shall never endure to see other shape of Man. O these trunk hose are a comely wearing.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I will be disguised directly. I will run through all the shapes of Jupiter, before I will again be prevented. Farewell. O my sweet! At seven in the evening expect me.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Sweet sayst thou? Thou art not I will swear. I am glad he was prevented. I should never held out a course with him, that cannot endure a breathing: a Cheese shop on fire cannot outstink him.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Your Uncle is gone Mistress, and says he will be here at seven a clock again. But shall I tell you a fine thing Mistress?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Yea marry Humfrey, what may that be and it is not of Sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: But it is of him Mistress. He says he will bring a Coach for you at six a clock to fetch you away: will you go with him?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: By my soul that will I if it be all the world over.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: How shall your Uncle find you at seven then?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: We will leave him at six and sevens. I mean betwixt both. It will be trim trust me. And hearest thou me Humfrey. Thou must bid Mistress Traynwell come to me a little before six; for a very good reason.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Hmh

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay, it shall hinder nothing. We will away the faster.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I think she be in her wits already. If not, I must humour her, though I be put to the trouble to shift her away again. She shall mar no sport that is certain.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Come with me Humfrey, thou shalt go even now, and tell her; and I will be packing up the while.-- -

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: This Clinches. I shall win my Ladies heart for ever. To manage two such businesses more, were enough to raise me Agent for a State.

div2.stage: The end of the fourth Act.
Act. V. Scene I. Pate in a Doctors habit. Traynwell, Constance.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: To discourse a tedious Lecture unto you, Lady, in speaking philosophically of the disease of Melancholy, were to show more learning than discretion. There are large volumes of it in Print, to very slender purpose.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, I desire rather your discretion, than the gloss of Learning. I am rather governed by the wholesome effects of the one, than the smooth directions of the other.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: To the point then Lady. I see no reason why I should vex and torment this delicate and tender body, with Physic. Her disease is Melancholy; The cause of this disease I have found apparently in the two hours probation since you left her with me, to be Love, which she hath so greedily taken in, that it hath overwhelmed her spirits, and turned the faculties of all her senses into a rude confusion, sending forth the use of them extravagantly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, I must not only approve, but applaud your skill. It is love indeed, And I am right glad that your opinion jumps with my own knowledge: for now I doubt not of your speedy address to the cure.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: It is done in three words. The Party that she loves, must be the Doctor, the Medicine, and the Cure.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, the Gentleman is below, he came with me, only I would not bring him to her sight without your approbation, fearing it might do hurt.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Pray call him up, on peril of my judgment.
Give me your hand Mistress. Constance. I have good news for you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: It is a long while sine I heard any.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: The Gentleman, whom you love best, shall be your bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: He is wed already Sir. Another wife would gar him be put down at gallows: and I would not be she for all the worldly good that ever I saw with both mine eyen. And on my conscience I will be none of his Ligby for twice to mickle.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: She prattles very prettily methinks. Married already? Sure Cupid shot you with a forked arrow out of his Crossbow. But what will you say Lady, if by my Art I render this Gentleman unmarried again, and a Suitor unto you presently?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Marry, shall I tell you what I will say sir? That deserves hanging worse than the other matter, you would poison his wife by your Art, would ye? and make your gown there the Hangman's fee the second time? It looks as it had been once his already; and you like such a Doctor I mun tell ye, by your leave. God bliss me from thee. Mistress. Traynwell where are you?

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Out of her wits say they? I fear she is wiser than all of us, that have to do with her. She knows my gown better than I do: for I have had but two hours acquaintance with it. It is no longer since I hired it of the hangman's Merchant a Broker. It might have been Lopus gown for aught I know.

div2.stage: Scene II. Enter Traynwell and Lucklesse to them.

sp.speaker: Tray.
sp.p: They are fallen out I think.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
O Mistress. Traynwell, for dear Charities sake have me soon
from this Man: for I will never take any thing at him. He talks of poisoning.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By my faith you wrong me: Nor of any poisoning purpose. I was but putting a case of

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Pray put up your Pipes sir. I like not your Music: troth nor his countenance neither. Sweet Mistress. Traynwell gar me be shut on him. Now all the joys of Immortality light on ye sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Is that the Gent?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes sir. Pray observe. But how fell you out sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I must first salute him by your favour. Sir, all the accumulations of honour shower down upon you.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.p: Sir. May you reap the whole harvest of your fruitful wishes.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Dear sir, keep further from him.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: But one word sweet Lady; and you shall have the whole benefit of his presence to yourself.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Be not afraid sweetheart, he dares not hurt sir Phillip.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: In troth he breathes too near him.

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.p: I will warrant you. What has he done to move her thus? I know not what this obscure Doctor is. But Master. Tridewell put me upon him; and his approved honesty has and must kill all mistrust in me.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Your Coach is ready at door you say.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes my most delicate Doctor.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: As you find her then, after a few words away with her. I have performed my part sir. I will hold the discreet Governess in talk in the next room.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.p: But one word call ye this?

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: I have done sweet soul. Lady I have instructed the gent. shall we leave them?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
One word, by your leave first Master. Doctor, and I will attend you. Sir not alone my Discretion, but my Reputation lies at stake: and I make no doubt of your nobleness upon your Kinsman's word, my Complotter in this business. Therefore while I hold argument with the Doctor (who shall by no means perceive our deceit) slip you away with her in your Coach, where Master. Tridewell hath appointed, till the Evening; and let me alone to scuffle with the old man the while. And then I doubt
not all our troublesome labours shall have a peaceable end. I will send old Madcap to your Lady in a Thunderclap. But noble sir, your reputation

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My life and honour be her Guard, and your security.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: No more sir. I will lay no conjurations upon so noble a spirit. Come Master Doctor

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But do you love me Constance ?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: O right well sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And will you be my Woman?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I is sure, I will never be mine own else.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you will not go away with me now, if I request you?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Any whither but to bed before we be married.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What from your Governess, your Uncle, and all the World?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: And thank you too sir. And take me but from this ill looking Doctor; for I shall be well with you sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, since you trust me so well, we two will not part till we are lawfully made one.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Heaven bliss the hour you speak in, and all Saints be witnesses.

div2.stage: Sce. III. Enter Squelch, meeting Trainewell, and Pate. Musick continues.

sp.speaker: Squ
sp.p: Where is this Doctor? where is this melancholy Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: O me is he come?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Is this her Uncle?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Even he sir. Where is my charge; Mistress Constance?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Save ye sir I will go find her

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Where is my charge? I will go find her! What is the meaning?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: She was here but now sir, while the Music played, And we withdrew ourselves, thinking she might sleep sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: There went a Coach away as I came in. Whose was it?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: A Coach sir? Alas I am afraid; my flesh trembles.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: At what in your great Master the Devils name? Where is my Niece?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir here came in one Master Widgine, the Lady Luckless brother

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: As acquainted with the Doctor sir

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: And he saw her sir. But seemed to depart, when we withdrew ourselves to talk about the cure.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Very very well. While you were wisely talking about the cure, a Widgine flies away with the Patient. Where is this Doctor? Doctor I say. Doctor! He is run away too, my life on it. A mere plot, a Conspiracy; it is so directly, below there. I cannot see how it can be otherwise.
Saw you the Doctor?
Yes sir, he went now forth at the water gate, and took boat in haste.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Exceeding well! How came your Discretion acquainted with this Doctor?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir he was reported to me by very good Judgments, to be a rare Practitioner.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: A most rare fellow, and does admirable tricks, by slight of heels. But I may perhaps outrun them

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: My purge works as I wished. I am amused though at the flight of the Doctor. But I have too many businesses to entertain new thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: May I believe it, Good sir? may I be so happy, that my brother has her?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: As I have truth in me, I am most credibly told so. Marry the worst is, her Uncle is so mad at their escape, that he will never give consent to the match, whereby her portion will be less.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Hang him Clod. My will shall be a portion sufficient to my brother, I care not, though he give her not a penny, so what has the Wench.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p:
Make you no more doubt of that, than I do Madam, who have upon the report of it already, prepared the Learned of the Civil Law, those that you nominated of your good acquaintance, and are forward to do you the best office,
who have appointed to meet before the Judge of the Archdeacons Court presently, whither I have promised to bring, and will attend you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: But the other side must be summoned by process.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sir Phillip hath warning already Madam; and without needless process will be there before you, and wait your coming. So that myself and his servant, who have never been both absent from one of your companies, since your Marriage, justly deposing you never did the realest Rite of Marriage, the bed office, Madam; you both consenting, and desiring a Divorce, It is instantly granted, without any proceedings in Law. So that all will be ended in three whispers. Odds pity, look who here is.

div2.stage: Sce. V. Enter Squelch to Fitchow.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: O are you here my Lady Luckless?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: It was time you found me sir; you might have mistaken my name else. For within this hour, I might have resumed the ancient title of your friend, and Awdery Fitchow.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Show wow, where is my Niece?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Where are your wits sir? you come upon me indeed! What Niece? What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: My Niece Constance, that your brother Widgine stole from the Doctor, and is flown away withal. But he must not think to scape so? I may take him, and his Duck too, in my Decoy, before they be coupled, as sure as your Ladyship, or your Fitchow ship, and they think yourselves.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sure the old Gentleman is fallen mad. What hath happened?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: The plot smells of your Ladyships policy; your Ladyships Lily white fist is foul in the business. But I will have a bout at fisticuffs in Law with your Ladyship: your great acquaintance, and alliance in the Whatshicall Court Non obstante. Your power there must not carry it, my great Lady. Directly it must not.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Your are an uncivil greasy Companion, to upbraid and revile me thus in my own house.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O good Madam, hurt not yourself with anger better laugh it out.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: He makes me forget myself by his example. Sir you are a Commissioner for the Peace I take it. Does it become a Man of your place and gravity, to fly out in these extremes? You spend too much breath in these loud notes, very hurtful to the Lungs. If you will fall into a lower Key, and speak peaceably, I will answer you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I pray you, Forsooth, or sweet Madam, or what you please; Where is my Niece?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Will you believe me sir? you may: For it is Truth, as I have any; And before this worthy Gentleman; I never saw your Niece in my life; only I have heard she is a pretty Gentlewoman: likely to make a good Match, for which I told my brother of her, and would have treated with you for her, could I have spoken with you as I wished by two or three Messages. But whither my brother has got her, or where he, or she is of my own knowledge, I cannot say directly.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: She mocks me to my face all this while. Well goodwife, Mistress, Madame

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well my Lord Innkeepers second Son: Does your Provender prick you?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Prick Madam! I tell thee thou Thing, made up of Chippings, broken Bear, Candle ends, and sifting of Sea cole.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Out you Curry-comb.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Forbear sweet Lady, let him be mad by himself.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I will be so revenged

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: How pray?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: He had been better to have killed a Man, ravished a Virgin; nay, done the most dangerous contempt that Law could devise to punish, than if I take him to suffer under my revenge.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I will muster up my Constables, and send out a privy search immediately.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What think you of your Brothers success, now Madam?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Much the better, that it vexes him so: Scurvy foul mouthed fellow.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Look you now Madam. See who here comes.

div2.stage: Sce. VII. Enter Widgine, Holdup, Howdee.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister fall down, and adore me for my great achievement. Humfrey kneel down to her that she may dub thee for thy service. Never did the best nosed Dogs, that ever were coached for their goodness, hunt more truly, take more bravely, and carry away more cleanly, than we have done this dainty piece of flesh here. Sister kiss her, and be better acquainted: she is mine own flesh, I will uphold it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: She is a Holdup herself, if I mistake not her name.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Being your flesh brother, her nearest affinity of blood runs in my veins. Therefore with a sisters love I embrace you, and bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Mine Uncle will by right wood I fear me. But I will near greet for that sir, while I have your love.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I know it is she by her tongue, though I never heard her before. Nor ever fear sweet sister, we shall be all friends shortly.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: I would be glad if it were so.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister come hither. Now hear and admire my wit, as well as my Fortune. Humfrey come and take thy share of my sisters wonder.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I hope I performed my duty.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which we must not see unrewarded sister.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: No: I mean to give him my Maid, and a hundred Marks with her, besides all she has about her.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I am made for ever. I thank your languishing Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well said Howdee: for my Ladyship is even at the last gasp. I am to be Divorced within this half hour. But your proceedings brother? How did she receive you at first?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O at first, she was the prettilyest mad that ever you saw. You yourself cannot devise to be so mad, as she was.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
And all for sir Phillip, she would love none but sir Phillip, speak to none but sir Phillip. I told her I was sir Phillip,
(ah God-a-mercy Humfrey; that was thy invention.) Then the little Viper hang upon me, not to be shaked off, till I promised her Marriage, and to father a Child, which, in her distraction, she conceited she had by me. I promised her anything; so took her into an inner room, to make all sure, as well within as without; and I so filliped her

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Enough brother, no more. I understand you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But I must have more, and shall never have enough on it. It passeth your understanding and mine too, the delight of it.
O what a delight she gave me. And how light I am after it. Heigh. My pretty sweet Rascal.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Enough I say.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You do not love to hear on it, because you lack it. But you shall hear the Miracle it wrought sister. The loss of her Maiden head recovered her wits. I made her right and straight in an instant. And now she loves me in my own person; knows me for a Widgine, and will not give her Wat for the best sir Phillip of them all. And longs for nothing but the Priest and Bed time. Ha my sweeter and sweeter! My Governer has gone for a Licence.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: So, have you done now?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Yet again.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That Humfrey, and I with the tricks and trinkets, we have about us will cure all the mad Maids of her standing in the Town. And do not think, but much may be gotten to profess it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You have made a large relation Master Widgine, and a pleasant, I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O I could live and die in this discourse sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Lady do you think of the time?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I will instantly along with you. Howdee come you with me. Brother, the search hath past this house already. You may do in with your Sweetheart, and stay here safely. Go in, and keep close, till I send to meet me at Supper.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: In and in sister, and be close enough, fear not

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Now sir when you please.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I am your servant Lady

div2.stage: Sce. VIII. Enter Traynwell and Vexhem.

sp.speaker: Uex.
sp.p: Mistress, I will go no further in this business, than you have limited me in your directions: it will be revenge enough for my disgrace to make him see his error.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Therefore be discreet and secret. The disguise he is in I have told you. The place is this. At the door you shall leave me. The hour seven o'clock.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Mistress, I will not watch more truly at Midnight, than I will pray for you for this Discovery. I will instantly call my privy search, guard, and catch a bird, of Justice in the lime-twigs of his own Warrant.

div2.stage:
Scene IX.
Enter Nonsense and Beauis.

sp.speaker: Nons.
sp.p: I tit not speak with Sir Paule then, it seems, to know the reason why I am subdoodled thus, In I protest and vow a kind of Pools Paradise.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Good sir bear your injury with a Man's patience. Sir Paule will not be long absent. And till he comes, my Mistress entreats you (for your own good) to take his part upon you, in giving entertainment to divers of his friends, who are invited hither to a Feast tonight.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Have you any Whitpots?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Much better meat sir. But here is the strangeness of it; and the only occasion that requires your aid in the entertainment. This great Supper or Feast (as I may properly call it) was appointed by Sir Paule himself, the money to buy the Provision delivered by his own hand, to his own Servant; the Guests of his own election; yet he, out of the multiplicity of cross affairs, that have happened this day, hath quite forgot that there was any such preparation, or any such meeting intended, as appears evidently by his absence. But my Mistress has got all the meat privately made ready at the next house, on purpose that he should see nothing

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: To try if he would forget it or no?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Right sir. I have bidden all the Guests: and expect them immediately.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: But what must I say to them?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Only salute them, bid them welcome; Tell them Sir Paule was hastily called forth on his Majesties affairs; Entreat their patience till his return, which you know will be very sudden although you know not where he is; and so forth, as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Your Master abroad and not within say you?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: Yes. But good sir stay his coming, I pray you, for his good.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I partly apprehend you at full. Mistress Traynwell appointed me to come too with all possible speed. Master. Nonsense you are well apprehended.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Only salute them, bid them welcome. Tell them Sir Paule was hastily called forth on his Majesties affairs. Entreat their patience till his return, which you know will be very sudden, although you know not where he is. And so forth as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Love has made you a Courtier. Master. Nonsense

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: No I protest and vow. I do but speak as they say.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: What have you said Sir?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: What you said I have an ill verbatim else.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I said but the meaning of what you should say, and put it in your own words.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: No sir. I will take your own words for this matter.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I am beholden to you.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: I am glad Fortune has sent one man of Civil government before the Roarers come. Here comes some of them already. I will down and look to the rest of the house.

div2.stage: Enter Lucklesse, Constance, disguis'd and Masqu'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Save you sir. Are you the Worshipful of the house?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend you sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Mistake me not I beseech you. I apprehend you to be some great stranger here: because you know the place better than the Master of it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You do not mock me sir?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, This is one of the Guests?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Only salute them. Bid them welcome

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What is this?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Tell them Sir Paule was hastily called forth on his Majesties affaires

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is this a Parrot or a Popinjay?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Entreat their patience till his return, which you know.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do you know what you say sir?

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: Will be very sudden, although you know not where he is

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If I did I would not seek him here sir.

sp.speaker: Non.
sp.p: And so forth as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is some enchanted Place, and the people are charmed. I have mistaken the house sure.

div2.stage: Enter Tridewell and Fitchow disguis'd and Masqu'd.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Where is this hospitable Knight that invites Strangers. I mean mere Strangers, that he knows not. Show me the Lad of bounty, I hunger not for his Supper as I do to salute him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He will prove the greatest stranger here himself I think, for he is not at home sir. I am a Guest as you are, and would be as glad to see him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He does not mean to jeer us does he?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I beseech you mistake not so his purpose sir: which is fair welcome, and good cheer to you all. Therefore Gentlemen and Ladies, will it please you to entertain one another a while.

milestone.n: Enter Cleark vvith Sack and Tobacco.

sp.p: Look ye. Here is good Sack, and good Tobacco. And before the rest of the Guests become, Sir Paule will be here himself.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This fellow speaks.

div2.stage: Enter Anv. Widg. Holdup, and Howdee disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Bul.
