sp.p: As I am a Justice of Peace I cannot apprehend, and yet methinks I do. What sort of people these Gentlemen may be. See: more! Is sir Paule turned swaggerer? Or is his house abused by servants? I will not leave it, until they go out before me like a Jail delivery. They look like men betwixt a Reprieve and Pardon. Friend: Are these sir Paules elected friends?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: His protected friends sir.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Protected?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
Aye sir. There is a fraternity of them. The brothers of
the Protect. There is not a man of them, but has all Mayors, Sheriffs, Bailiffs, Sergeants at Mace, Marshalls men, Constables, and other his Majesties Officers, in a Comb-case in his pocket. They are a Generation that never eat but in Parliament time, and now every table is full of them.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I should wonder what they did here else. See. A roaring Doctor too, broke out of the Kings Bench.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By your leave Gallants. I perceive your Company is not yet full.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Are you of the invited sir?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: It is not to be doubted sir. Yet a Voluntary. But there are some without that are more than invited, yet come against their wills.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How mean you Master. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Pa
sp.p: Brought sir by a Constable and Officers, to be examined. Where is the jolly Justice?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What are they can ye tell sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman, and a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: A Spaniard, Ha!

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Aye, a Spaniard, Ha: if you will have it so:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If we had but a Justice among us to Examine them, it might pass the time well till sir Paule came.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Justice, and for the same purpose too for aught we know, that shall not refuse to do it, and in sir Paules Gown and Cap too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is a witty fellow.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, you cannot do a more acceptable office for your friend, than to execute his place in his absence. Your authority makes you capable of it; and I do the rather persuade it, because the Gentlemen whom you wisely suspect for loose persons, may see some example of Justice; which may prevent some present evil in their stay here.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend you friend. Give me the Gown and Chair, and let the Delinquents approach. Vmh, vmh.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It is a Spaniard indeed.

div2.stage: Enter Vexhem, Squelch, like a Spaniard, Trayn. Cleark.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p:
An English Spaniard sir. And therefore the verier
knave: as will be proved I doubt not, to his shame, and my renown in the Common wealth. By your Worships leave.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: What news bring you Master. Constable?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Spanish news sir. Will it please your Worship to examine the virtue of my Warrant, and then these Persons accordingly?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Very good! I am brought before myself to be examined, and before a fine rabble too! how the devil broke this unknown Nation into my house, or do not I mistake it? My foolery has led me into a fine predicament. I will not yet disclose myself: but look a little further towards the event.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Are you a Spaniard sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Such a one as you see Seignior.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: See Seignior. He speaks nothing but Spanish. The question will be how we shall understand this Examinant.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hey day!

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I do see Seignior I thank the light, that you are a goodly man of outward parts, and except it were the black Knight himself, or him with the Fistula, the properest man I have seen of your Nation. They are a People of very spare diet, I have heard, and therefore seldom fat. Sure you you have had most of your breeding in this Country, the diet whereof you like better than your own, which makes you linger here, after all your Country men, upon some uncouth plot. And I shall wonder therefore how you can speak no English. Can you speak no English at all sir? Answer me I pray.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Not an English word not I sir. Alas I have not been five days in the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is excellent!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Aye, peace. You will mar all if you laugh.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Alas, what shall we do then? Gentlemen, have any of you any Spanish, to help me to understand this strange Stranger?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Not a Royal sir not I.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nor a Royals worth amongst us of any Language but sheer English.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: What Shire of our Nation is next to Spain? Perhaps he may understand that Shire English.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Devonshire or Cornwall sir.

sp.speaker: Non
sp.p: Never credit me, but I will spout some Cornish at him. Peden bras vidne whee bis cregas.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Am I transformed utterly? Is my Language altered with my apparel, or are you all mad? what unspeakable misery is this.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I see we shall never understand, nor do good on him, till he be instructed in the English tongue.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: If it please your worship, the best University for this purpose will be Bridewell. I am acquainted with the best Tutors there, Master Cleanewhip, Master Dri-lash, and divers others.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: You officious Rascal, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: No such matter sir. But in my right mind, and Middlesex fear it not.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: It must be so. His instruction will cost little there, if he be not too old to learn. Therefore set him by, and let me fall upon the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: O, he is rarely vexed.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Now Gentlewoman, will it please you to be unmasked.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes sir look you, I dare show my face.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Mistress Trainewell, as I apprehend.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Mistress Trainewell.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Trainewell!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Even she Gentlemen, as I will more circumstantially reveal unto you presently, after a word or two with my fellow prisoner, for which I crave your favour.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: With all my heart, so you can speak Spanish and make him understand you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You see I am not the Woman you took me for: but one ordained for your greater good. If you will give me my present demand, I will turn all your disgrace into laughter; make you of worthier esteem now at the instant, than ever you were, by the general approbation of these, and all that know you beside. Your Niece too shall be restored to your own liking, and all shall be as well as you can wish. Otherwise, if you have a mind to be everlastingly shamed, by being perpetually laughed at, take your own course, I will take mine.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I am astonished. What is your Demand?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Whereas your purpose was to make a Whore. Make me your honest Wife; no more. Be sudden in your resolve, all will be naught else.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
I am in a mischievous straight then. Redime te captum. Thy wit deserves my love. I will do it; here is my hand and faith, I will
do it. Thou art mine, and I am thine directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Then hark you sir.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: Sir what will you say, if this Gentlewoman convert the Spaniard, turn him true English subject, and present him to you with the oaths of Allegiance, and Supremacy in his mouth presently?

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I will say, she deserves for ever hereafter to hold her peace.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Now bear up sir. Look confidently, and say, you put on your Disguise purposely to entertain disguised Guests. Come avaunt with your Picca de goat, and begin with the Justice here.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Thou hast made me a Man for ever, and I will make thee a Woman directly. Gallants save you. See here the Metamorphosis, that means to metamorphose you all. Alas I know you for all your Disguises, and thought to entertain you in your kind.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Sir Paul Squelch!

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: First out of you, my Usurper, and most upstartical Justice, whose office is your trade, and Clerk your Prentice, I will draw a man of little, or no Moment: yet my friend, and Master Bullfinch, out of the Chair of Justice. This may prognosticate the putting of myself, or many others out of Commission within these few years; though I am no Prophet. Do I speak English now? Do I know you now, or you me?

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Questionless, we should know one another sir Paul: or else one of us two were both very ignorant.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: To proceed in my Metamorphosis. I will change you most confused Roarer, into an accomplished Knight. And bid you welcome, noble sir Phillip Luckless.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I like the change well, and thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Next sir of you Roarer, or Iierer, or whatsoever you are, I will make a complete Gentleman, most answerable to your name Master Tridewell.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: But out of you Master Doctor, I will pick a certain Knave. Where is my Niece sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Which of your Nieces sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Have I so many sir? I mean my only one Constance, find her me, or I will translate you out of an Aesculapian Cock into a Newgate bird immediately.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir if you will Metamorphose me out of a Bachelor, into a Bridegroom, I will show you your Niece.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: This my Niece?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: O have I found you Mistress? Sir this is the Gentlewoman I brought before your worship today.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hold thy peace; art in thy right mind?

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: As I am in my right mind and Middlesex, it is she sir. I had not matter enough then to lay to her charge; for which I thank your worship I kissed Newgate. But now I have sir; she has left a Child upon our Parish, I am sure got by an unknown father; and has been a loose Liver, both at Duke Humfreyes, and most of the winked at houses about the Town these four years: which I can sufficiently prove.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hold thy peace Knave. I will put these plums in thy mouth else

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Sir, my Child shall trouble your Parish no longer, here is a Father, my troth plight Husband, sufficient to keep it and me, wilt thou not Duck?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Duck? my name is Widgine, you mistake the man sure.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Sure I do not. This Gentleman, and this Gentlewoman, and this trusty Servant of ours are my witnesses, I am your Wife sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O I am undone, quite cast away. Sister help me now with your Law wit, or I perish for ever.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: This is not to be endured: cheating, and vile abuse. This contract cannot be lawful. One person mistaken for another a lawful impediment to be divorced for, though they were married.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: It might do well if (as he confesses himself) he had not made all too sure, as well within as without.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sir Phillip, while they wrangle out their cause, let us agree: Find you but the means to make her lawfully your Wife, and here take her with my faithful promise, of the equal half of my estate presently.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir Paul I thank you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I say this is no lawful contract: And though we are legally divorced, yet neither he nor I, may lawfully marry, while we both live, having been lawfully married. And till you can disprove that, sir I will forbid your Banes good sir Phillip, and lay your hopes a cooling, friendly Master Tridewell, for your love in managing this business.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Lady give me leave, if I have strained a point of friendship, it was your love gave the strength to my wit.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: My love?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Your love indeed Lady. Which (and which Cupid pardon me for) now, that I see I may enjoy, I am not so eagerly taken with, yet if you will

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
Sir you cannot enjoy me, nor he her, less you can disprove
the lawfulness of our former Marriage.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: To clear that point, do you know the Minister?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: It is not so long since, but I can remember his face.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Then to continue sir Pauls Metamorphosis? I will draw him out of this Doctor. Is not this he?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: It is. But is not he a lawful Minister; I would know that.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: To clear that doubt there lies my Order of Priesthood.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Who, Oliver !

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Even he, the Parson Nochurch, and this my Patron, whom I must beseech together with the whole company, to preserve me out of the high Commission: for look you, here is again your Licence.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Would you do this Master Tridewell?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Faith I foresaw an untowardness in the Match: which if you repent the breach of, there is your Licence; and the way to Church lies before you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: No sir. First get my brother free of his contract, and then a Licence with your own name, and I will wait on you to Church, as soon as you will.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O that is done already. What are you agreed?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Most happily sir, sister all is well again. I have given her a hundred pound to relinquish her right in me. Which afore all these witnesses you do; do you not?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Yes most freely.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well then, I will not forswear to marry, But if ever I steal a Wife again, let her be a witch, and may I burn with her for company. Governor, thou art out of countenance, and thou too honest Humfrey, methinks. Come bear up. I forgive. It was your errors, not malice.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir for my part, I will take my corporal oath

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It shall not need good Humfrey.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And for me sir

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, I dare not but believe thee before thou speakest Governor: therefore prithee let us not talk on it ourselves, but quietly, and presently begin our travels, that we may hear nobody else talk on it.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Ladies, I see you all at peace so well, that I wish no further content to any, except Master Nonsense here.

sp.speaker: Nons.
sp.p: Never credit me, but I have had sport enough of conscience, and if I do not make a Stage play on it, when I come into Cornwall: I protest and vow then say there was Nonsense in this.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I am glad you conclude so friendly with the rest. All the unquietness will be in the Kitchen presently If your meat stay for you. Gallants.

It was time to speak. They knock at Dresser already. Will ye in?
You are all welcome: And I wish every Guest as merry, as our Northern Lasses Feast.
